Accessibility Statement
3 months ago Updated
Follow

We are committed to making our products as accessible as possible to everyone, including those with visual, hearing, cognitive, and motor impairments.

We are consistently working to improve the overall accessibility of our product by aiming to meet the Website Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG) 2.0 Level AA. These guidelines explain how to make website content more accessible for those who need it.

✅ WCAG2.0 Level A, AA

✅ WCAG2.1 Level A, AA

✅ Revised Section 508

Main accessibility features

Screen reader compatibility

Our products support popular screen readers including VoiceOver, NVDA and JAWS. 

Keyboard navigation

All features are designed, implemented and tested with keyboard compatibility in mind.

Use of ARIA

As we have a dynamic platform, we have used various ARIA roles, properties and states to enhance screen reader users' experience.

We recommend you use a modern browser with a modern screen reader to take advantage of these features.

Visual Design

All pages and content may be enlarged using standard browser controls or screen magnification software. Text on pages is designed to have sufficient contrast with its background.

Contact us

We’d be happy to hear any feedback you may have on the accessibility of the Engageli platform and product. If you encounter any barriers while on our platform please email accessibility@engageli.com.

Low bandwidth mode

You will not see individual engagement markers such as the green dots or raised hands.
Learner video feeds are turned off when they raise their hands to speak on the podium and in the table mates gallery when you visit individual tables.
You will still hear each learner’s audio.

To switch to low bandwidth mode:

Click the More Actions (three dots) menu at the bottom of your screen.
Select Low bandwidth mode. 

When to use:

If audio, video, or screen shares are cutting out, dropping or generally low quality.
When you have low internet bandwidth
When you are using an older computer

If you are having trouble running a poll or quiz on Engageli, make sure that the Tags are large enough and placed correctly on your document of choice.

If you get a 'Tag Not Found' error, this means that Engageli does not recognize your poll or quiz Tag. To resolve:

Ensure the Tags are large enough on your document or slide. They must be at least 75x75 px in size.
Ensure that the Tag is within the document or slide boundary. If they run outside the document or slide boundary, they will be cut off and will not work. 
Ensure that you are sharing your document or slides in full screen (present mode).

Once your Canvas Administrator has set up the Engageli LTI external tools in Canvas LMS, you will be able to add the Engageli Class Browser Access and Engageli Instructor App Launcher to your Canvas course(s).  

Prerequisites:  

Canvas administrator needs to set up the Engageli LTI external tools. Instructions here.
Instructors need to download the Engageli Instructor desktop application.

 

Reminder: There are 2 LTI components of a Canvas Engageli class. 

Engageli Class browser launcher. This is added to the course, so students can access Engageli via Chrome / Edge browser (recommended) directly from the Canvas course.
Engageli Instructor app launcher. This is added to the course, so Instructors can launch the Engageli Instructor App directly from their Canvas course.
Steps: 

1. In the Canvas course, select “Module”. Add title and “Add Module.”

2. Add Item to the module by selecting External Tool from the dropdown menu. Select the tool from the list (Engageli Class Browser or Instructor App Launcher). Add Item. If you don’t see the Engageli external tool listed, contact your Canvas admin.

 

3. Important: Edit the Module details to make sure the tool loads in a new tab.

 

4. For Student access, make sure you “Publish” the module. Instructor App launcher can stay unpublished to prevent students from viewing it.

9 months ago Updated
Follow

Basic Troubleshooting

Troubleshooting During Class

Troubleshooting Headsets

 
Basic Troubleshooting

1. Check that you are using a computer or laptop to run class. We currently do not support mobile or tablet devices. If you are using one of these, please join Engageli via a laptop, computer, or Chromebook.

2. Check that you are on an Engageli-supported browser. We currently do not recommend Safari or Firefox browsers. If you are using one of these, please join Engageli via the latest version of Google Chrome, Edge, or a browser on Chromium (Opera, Vivaldi, Brave).

3. Refresh the browser. Sometimes, simply refreshing the browser can resolve an audio issue. 

4. Check your computer’s permissions (Mac | Windows). Check the privacy and security settings for your computer’s Microphone, and make sure they are set to On and that desktop apps have access to the Microphone. 

 

Troubleshooting During Class

Check your device's sound output and make sure the correct devices are connected. You can check your speaker output in your settings (gear icon). This will open a media device settings window where you can toggle which speaker Engageli is using. 

Troubleshooting Headsets


Note: If you are running an additional audio/video platform, this can sometimes prevent Engageli from accessing your audio device.

Bluetooth headphones:


Disconnect your headphones from your computer.

Turn your headphones off or put your earbuds in their charging case.

Check that the audio works on your internal computer speakers.

Turn your headphones back on or remove your earbuds from their case.

Reconnect your headphones or earbuds to your computer.

USB headphones:


Disconnect your headphones from your computer’s USB port.

Check that the audio works on your internal computer speakers.

Plug your headphones into a different port, if possible.


1/8” (3.5mm) connector headphones:

Remove your headphones from your computer’s 1/8” jack.

Check that the audio works on your internal computer speakers.

Plug your headphones back into the 1/8” jack.


Click here for information about the audio settings in an Engageli classroom.

If you are having trouble logging into Engageli from a web browser, check your browser extensions.

 

While there is no way to block Engageli's authentication login window (even if you have blocked pop-ups and redirects), it is possible that you have installed browser extensions that can block pop-up windows. 

 

Instructions

1. To manage your extensions on Google Chrome, click the Extensions puzzle piece icon to the right of the URL address bar.

 

2. Click Manage Extensions from the drop-down menu.

3. Click Details to get a better sense as to whether or not the extension could be blocking Engageli's login window. If the extension says "ad block" or "pop up blocker," it is possible that the extension is blocking the window from opening.

 

4. Click Remove and try again.

If you're having issues with speaking to your tablemates and/or class, make sure your microphone is on and you have given Engageli permission to connect.

 

Instructions

1. Check that you are using a computer or laptop to run class. We currently do not support mobile or tablet devices. If you are using one of these, please join Engageli via a laptop, computer, or Chromebook.

2. Check that you are on an Engageli-supported browser. We currently do not recommend Safari or Firefox browsers. If you are using one of these, please join Engageli via the latest version of Google Chrome, Edge, or a browser on Chromium (Opera, Vivaldi, Brave). If needed, try switching to a different browser. If you are using Chrome, try using Edge or another supported browser, or vice versa.

3. Refresh the browser. Sometimes, simply refreshing the browser resolves a camera issue.

4. Check your computer’s permissions (Mac | Windows). Check the privacy and security settings for your computer’s Microphone, and make sure they are set to On and that desktop apps have access to the Microphone.

You can archive inactive classes you previously taught on Engageli in the Admin Portal. If you need to access data from a past class, the class can be restored at any time.

Archiving a class is a ‘soft delete’ that removes the class from the Class Management list in the Admin Portal. The class roster, tables and presets, analytics, Q&A threads, content, polls, etc. are all left unchanged. 

Instructions
1. Go to the Admin Portal.
2. Click Classes (Class Management in v3.0) on the left to expand the menu.
3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class.
4. Click Details.
5. Under the General tab, click Archive Class.
6. Then, click Confirm.

To restore an archived class:
1. Go to the Admin Portal.
2. Click Archived Classes on the left to expand the menu.
3. Select your archived class or use the search field to find it.
4. Click Details.
5. Under the General tab, click Restore Class.
6. Click Confirm to restore the class and move it back to the Class Management menu.

Note: Selecting Delete Class, and then clicking Delete to confirm will completely delete the class and it cannot be restored.

Using Tables for Active Learning - Browser
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Engageli tables are strategically designed to increase collaboration between learners. Tables are built so learners will always be in small groups and you do not need to create breakout rooms for group activities. This allows you to create rich learning experiences at the tables while learners also feel simultaneously connected to the larger class and the instructor.

 

Joining Tables

Creating Random Tables Groups 

Moving learners to different Tables

 

Joining Tables

Joining tables allows you to leave the podium and “visit” groups of learners at tables, much like “walking the room” in an in-person class. This is great for any group work or discussions.

Instructions
1. To join a table, click the Tables tab.
2. Hover over the table that you'd like to join and click the JOIN button.

When you join the table, you will see, hear, and interact only with members of the table you joined. This is great when groups have a question on an in-class assignment and you don't want to interrupt the entire class.

3. When you are ready to leave the table, click the Back to podium button. Engageli 3.1 users have several options for returning to the podium.

Note: The audio will automatically switch from Room Mode to Table Mode. When you leave the table, you will have to switch the audio setting back to Room Mode to enable a full-class discussion. Click to learn more about the audio settings.

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, instructors will peek at or observe tables unobtrusively without disturbing the learners. 

 
Creating Random Tables Groups 

This is a great way to encourage learner engagement is to randomly arrange table groups for discussions. 

Instructions

1. Go to the Seating Arrangement drop-down menu in the Tables view. 

2. Select Random Arrangement Table Size.

3. Choose the number of learners you would like at each table. The system will automatically break learners into randomized groups.

You can also reserve any of the first 3 tables for staff or other participants who you don't want to move during the random arrangement. In Engageli 3.0, this is called Skip Tables.

Note: If learners have a reservation, then they will be treated as learners. Make sure to remove any reservations before you do this! (See instructions on reservations here).

You can save the table arrangement you created as a preset that you can use again. Click for information on how to create a table preset during a class.

 

Moving Learners to Different Tables 

Instructions
1. Navigate to the Tables view.
2. Click the profile icon of the learner you wish to move.

3. Choose a new table for the learner from the drop-down menu.

4. Or, you can simply drag and drop the learner to a different table.

Engageli Sub-Rooms
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone


With Engageli sub-rooms instructors can divide their classes into separate section rooms for large group work and differentiated instruction.



Easily navigate between the main classroom and sub-rooms.
Promote TAs to the instructor role within sub-rooms.
Send announcements to all or specific rooms.

To get started with sub-rooms:

Set Up
Enable Sub-Rooms in Your Live Class
Learner Access
Instructor Controls
Moving Learners to Different Rooms
Set Up

Create a Sub-Room Set

1. Go to the Admin Portal.

2. Click Class Management on the left to expand the menu.

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class.

4. Select Sub-rooms from the menu on the left.

5. Click the plus sign (+) button in the top right corner to create a set of sub-rooms.

6. Then, select Active to make the set available in the classroom.

Note: At this time, you can create only one set of sub-rooms. 

 

Add Sub-Rooms to Your Set

1. Click the down arrow to the right of your sub-room set to expand the menu. 

2. Click Add First Sub-Room.

3. Enter the name of the sub-room.

4. Enter the number of tables you want in the sub-room. (You can have up to 20 tables in a sub-room, and each sub-room can have its own number of tables.)

5. Click Add.

 

Manage Sub-Room Set - In order to enable sub-rooms in your live class, you have to make sure the set is marked as Active in the Admin Portal. 

1. You can simply select or unselect the radio button below the label “Active.”

2. You can also activate or deactivate the set of sub-rooms by clicking the check box to the right of the name.

3. Then, click the edit icon.

4. Select or deselect “Active.”

5. Click Save. 

Note: If the set is not activated before the live session, you will have to end the class, go to the Admin Portal, and make it active.



Enable Sub-Rooms in Your Live Class

To enable learners to join the sub-rooms, select Enable sub-rooms mode from the More Actions (three dots) menu at the bottom of the screen.


Upon enablement, the sub-rooms will become available and all users will see “Sub-rooms”  in the My View menu.

Notes: 

When sub-rooms are enabled, they become available and are all “unlocked,” meaning they are open for participants to enter. 
If sub-rooms are left enabled when a classroom is closed, they will remain enabled for the next class session. 
These sub-rooms will be locked until specifically unlocked by the instructor.
Sub-rooms have the same class controls as the main room. To record a sub-room, the recording must be started in the main room. All rooms will be recorded in separate videos.
Learners joining an Engageli classroom using the Engageli for Learners iOS app cannot join a classroom with sub-rooms. 

 

Learner Access

Once sub-rooms are enabled, everyone in the classroom can see them by selecting “Sub-rooms” in the “My View” menu.

If the rooms are unlocked, the Join button will be enabled and any participant can move to that sub-room

If the rooms are locked, the Join button will be grayed out and disabled. 





To join a different room or go back to the main room, select "Sub-rooms" from the "My View" menu and then click Join for whichever room you want to enter.





Instructor Controls

In the sub-rooms view, instructors can

Lock /unlock all sub-rooms
Lock/unlock an individual sub-room
Send an announcement to 
All sub-rooms
Individual sub-rooms
See who is in each sub-room
Join any sub-room 
Move a participant to any sub-room or back to the main room

The three-dot menu to the right of each sub-room gives you the option to send a message to that specific room or lock the room. Locking the room means that no learners can join. If there are learners in a room that is locked, they will be sent to the main room. 

A TA can assume the instructor role in a sub-room. Click here to learn more. 





Moving Learners to Different Rooms

The Engageli Action Tags Lab provides tags that you can use to run an entire class session.

Including tags in your presentation slides and documents will reduce the cognitive load and orchestration required to conduct and manage your class, as the system automatically detects and presents you with the option to quickly enable the action. This frees up more of your time to focus on delivering the content you love, teaching in a more engaging way, and providing a smooth learning experience for your class.

To get tags that you can add to your slides and documents:

Go to the Admin Portal.
Select Action Tags Lab from the menu on the left.
Click on the tag type you would like to copy or download for use in your presentation.
Select from the various tag options and name your tag. The name of the tag chosen above in step 4 will be displayed when the poll is activated in your presentation.
If you have a poll with three choices, you can rename the tag and download one for each choice, then insert them into your presentation.
Alternatively if you'd prefer, you can manually add text to your presentation above or below the tag to indicate each choice. 
Click Copy or Download.
Once downloaded, you can add the tag to your presentation.
More information on how to activate tags in class below.
  Action Tags Lab 

To turn on auto detection of tags included in PDFs shared with the PDF Live Share:

1. Go to the Admin Portal.

2. Click Class Management on the left to expand the menu.

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class.

4. In the Details section, go to Configuration.

5. Check “Activate Engageli Tags automatically (PDF Only).”

6. Click the Save button.

To activate a tag in a presentation during a screen share:

1. Share your screen with the presentation containing the tags you want to activate.

2. Click the Activate Tag (QR code) button.

3 months ago Updated
Follow

You can easily show a high-resolution presentation without sharing your screen. Change slides faster and avoid common screen share issues.

The PDF Share [PDF Live Share in Engageli 3.0] allows you to share a PDF of a presentation or document directly in Engageli instead of sharing your screen. This allows you to share presentations with better visual quality for learners with minimal lag time. This article will show you how to: 

Upload PDFs in the Content Manager Before Class
Use the PDF Live Share During Class
View Class Gallery

 

Upload PDFs in the Content Manager Before Class

Instructions

1. Go to the Admin Portal.

2. Click Class Management on the left to expand the menu. 

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class. 

4. Click Content Manager.

5. Click the +Add button on the top right side of the screen.

6. Select Upload Files.

7. Upload the file from your computer.

8. You will see a notification at the bottom of the screen when the file is successfully uploaded.

9. Click the pencil icon below Download/Edit to make changes to the title of the file or add a description.

10. Click Save after making any changes.

 

Use the PDF Live Share During Class

Instructions

1. Click the Present button at the bottom of the screen.

2. Click PDF Share [PDF Live Share in Engageli 3.0] under Classroom activities.

3. Click Share on a pre-loaded file.

4. Or, drag & drop or click to select a file from your computer.

5. After the file uploads, click Share.

Note: TAs and learners on the podium can also navigate the presentation.

Pro Tip! Turn on auto-detection for tags in the Admin Portal so that any Action Tags (polls, timer, recording, etc.) are auto-activated when you give your presentation.

View Class Gallery

In Engageli 3.1, a view of the Class Gallery opens in the right pane when you're using the PDF Share so that you have a view of your learners during your presentation. You can open and close the Gallery as needed. 

Instructors using Engageli 3.0, can you use the Popped Gallery: 

1. Click the Show Popped Gallery icon in the right corner of the screen.

2. The Class Gallery will open in a small pop-up window.

3. Move the Class Gallery window to wherever you want it on screen.

Note: You can also use the overlay gallery feature.

Enter your username.

Review the Terms of Service and tap Agree & Continue.

To change your display name, click the edit icon in the upper right corner.

Engageli allows instructors to switch between the instructor and TA roles to provide more flexibility in the classroom.

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, instructors can easily elevate any learner to the TA or instructor role during the live session. 


Anyone listed on the roster in the portal as an instructor can:

Change their role within the classroom between instructor and TA.

To change your role:

1. Click the More Actions (three dots) menu at the bottom of your screen.
2. Select TA Role.

3. After a few seconds, you will leave the podium and join the other learners and TAs in the Class Gallery. 

Note: If you change your role to TA while the classroom is in Table Mode, you will have to raise your hand and go to the podium to address the entire class. To change your role back to the instructor, go back to the More Actions menu and select Instructor Role.

If you are teaching using Google Chrome or Edge and another instructor joins your classroom as a TA and then elevates themselves to the instructor, you will then become a TA.

Team Teaching

1. Click the Actions (three dots) menu in the TA's video feed in the Class Gallery.

2. Select Make Instructor.

3. After a few seconds, the TA will be elevated to instructor and you will move to the Class Gallery as a TA.

3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone


With Engageli sub-rooms instructors can divide their classes into separate section rooms for large group work and differentiated instruction.



Easily navigate between the main classroom and sub-rooms.
Promote TAs to the instructor role within sub-rooms.
Send announcements to all or specific rooms.

To get started with sub-rooms:

Set Up
Enable Sub-Rooms in Your Live Class
Learner Access
Instructor Controls
Moving Learners to Different Rooms
Set Up

Create a Sub-Room Set

1. Go to the Admin Portal.

2. Click Class Management on the left to expand the menu.

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class.

4. Select Sub-rooms from the menu on the left.

5. Click the plus sign (+) button in the top right corner to create a set of sub-rooms.

6. Then, select Active to make the set available in the classroom.

Note: At this time, you can create only one set of sub-rooms. 

 

Add Sub-Rooms to Your Set

1. Click the down arrow to the right of your sub-room set to expand the menu. 

2. Click Add First Sub-Room.

3. Enter the name of the sub-room.

4. Enter the number of tables you want in the sub-room. (You can have up to 20 tables in a sub-room, and each sub-room can have its own number of tables.)

5. Click Add.

 

Manage Sub-Room Set - In order to enable sub-rooms in your live class, you have to make sure the set is marked as Active in the Admin Portal. 

1. You can simply select or unselect the radio button below the label “Active.”

2. You can also activate or deactivate the set of sub-rooms by clicking the check box to the right of the name.

3. Then, click the edit icon.

4. Select or deselect “Active.”

5. Click Save. 

Note: If the set is not activated before the live session, you will have to end the class, go to the Admin Portal, and make it active.



Enable Sub-Rooms in Your Live Class

To enable learners to join the sub-rooms, select Enable sub-rooms mode from the More Actions (three dots) menu at the bottom of the screen.


Upon enablement, the sub-rooms will become available and all users will see “Sub-rooms”  in the My View menu.

Notes: 

When sub-rooms are enabled, they become available and are all “unlocked,” meaning they are open for participants to enter. 
If sub-rooms are left enabled when a classroom is closed, they will remain enabled for the next class session. 
These sub-rooms will be locked until specifically unlocked by the instructor.
Sub-rooms have the same class controls as the main room. To record a sub-room, the recording must be started in the main room. All rooms will be recorded in separate videos.
Learners joining an Engageli classroom using the Engageli for Learners iOS app cannot join a classroom with sub-rooms. 

 

Learner Access

Once sub-rooms are enabled, everyone in the classroom can see them by selecting “Sub-rooms” in the “My View” menu.

If the rooms are unlocked, the Join button will be enabled and any participant can move to that sub-room

If the rooms are locked, the Join button will be grayed out and disabled. 





To join a different room or go back to the main room, select "Sub-rooms" from the "My View" menu and then click Join for whichever room you want to enter.





Instructor Controls

In the sub-rooms view, instructors can

Lock /unlock all sub-rooms
Lock/unlock an individual sub-room
Send an announcement to 
All sub-rooms
Individual sub-rooms
See who is in each sub-room
Join any sub-room 
Move a participant to any sub-room or back to the main room

The three-dot menu to the right of each sub-room gives you the option to send a message to that specific room or lock the room. Locking the room means that no learners can join. If there are learners in a room that is locked, they will be sent to the main room. 

A TA can assume the instructor role in a sub-room. Click here to learn more. 





Moving Learners to Different Rooms

Move Individual Learners

Instructions

1. Under My View, select Sub-rooms.

2. Click Switch to List View.


3. Select the learner who you want to move.

4. From the drop-down menu, select the room where you want to move the learner. 

 

Move All Learners Back to the Main Room

Instructions

1. Under My View, select Sub-rooms.

2. Select the Lock All Rooms button.

3. Click OK to confirm that you want to lock all rooms and send everyone back to the main room of the class.





Move Learners from a Specific Sub-Room Back to the Main Room

Instructions

1. Under My View, select Sub-rooms.

2. Click the three dots to the right of the sub-room you want to lock.

3. Select Lock room.

4. Click OK to confirm that you want to lock this specific room and send all participants back to the main room of the class.

How to Access Engageli’s Attendance Analytics
Attendance Analytics Overview
How to Access Engageli’s Attendance Analytics

Follow these instructions to access Engageli’s Attendance Analytics in the Admin Portal:

Go to the Admin Portal.
Click Classes (Class Management in v3.0) on the left to expand the menu.
Select your class or use the search field to find your class.
Click Analytics.
Select Attendance.
Toggle between Chart and List View to see the data. To see a list of individual users, click on List View.
Select Export CSV to download the data.
Attendance Analytics Overview

Attendance Analytics displays the number of attendees for a class session (live and playback). Engageli measures the total minutes of each class session as well as the minutes each participant attended. Engageli measures the percentage of class session time a participant attended each class session, whether synchronously or asynchronously in an Engageli Playback Room. You can filter by participant: learners, staff, and guests. You also filter by class type: Live (synchronous) or Playback (asynchronous).

Attendee - Individual who attends a class session (live or playback)
Attendance (%) - Average percentage of class sessions with “present” attendance across all classes held during the specified time period
Attendance tracking for participants is based on the participant attending at least 60% of the instructor's attendance. If an instructor is logged in for a 1-hour session, the participant needs to attend the session for at least 36 minutes in order to be marked as present. 
Lecture duration - The total scheduled class time
Presence (HH:MM) - Amount of time participants spent in class (compared to the total class time), based on the scheduled time
Offline or Playback room attendance - Participant watched at least 60% of the recorded class time. If the recorded session is below 60% of the class time, attendance is not marked as present even if the participant watches the entire recorded session.

Chart View

List View

Name 
Email address - Email address listed on the roster
Attendance (%) - Percentage of classes attended marked “present”
Classes - Total number of scheduled classes (within the selected date range)
Red bar - “absent”
Green bar - “present”
Presence (HH:MM)

3 months ago Updated

 It's easy to record and share class recordings within Engageli so you and your learners can revisit class discussions, content, and material as needed!

Recording Settings (Pre-Class)

1. To access recording settings, go to the Admin Portal. 

2. Click Classes [Class Management in Engageli 3.0] on the left to expand the menu. 

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class. 

4. Click Details.

5. Select the Configuration tab.

6. Check Record learners' videos if you want to include in the class recordings the video feeds of learners who raise their hands to join the podium. If this option is unchecked, only the learners' audio will be captured in the recording.  

7. Check Auto start recording if you want the recording to automatically start after you log in and launch the classroom. This is helpful in case you forget to start the class recording.

Note: Settings will persist between class sessions. This means the setting(s) you selected most recently will be the default for future classes unless you change it. 

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, instructors and admins have options to record the Class Gallery and make the recording private by default.

 

Recording During Class 

1. Once the class has started, click the green dot (Record Lecture) to begin recording. Engageli 3.1 users click the Record button at the bottom of the screen. 

2. While recording, you can pause, stop, or continue the recording at any time.  

3. If you want to pause the recording, click the red dot (Stop Recording). Engageli 3.1 users click the Record button to pause. 

4. If/when you want to resume the recording, click the green dot (Record Lecture) again. Engageli 3.1 users click the Record button again to resume.

5. The recording will stop when class ends.

After class, a link to the recording will be emailed to the email address that you used to sign into Engageli. Each instructor listed on the roster will receive the email. The recording link is sent from a "do not reply" address, so if you don’t see it within five minutes to one hour, please check your Spam folder. 

Click here to learn which components are included in the class recording and ways you can optimize the recording for asynchronous learning in the Playback Room.

Recording Indicator 

When the class is being recorded, a red dot will appear in the top right corner of the instructor's video. Learners and instructors on the browser will see the following:

 

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, in addition to the red dot, all users will see and hear a notification whenever the recording starts or is paused.

Recordings After Class

After class, you can access recordings in the Admin Portal. 

1. Under your class, go to Recordings and you will see a list of all recordings.

2. You can easily change the name of the recordings by clicking the titles listed under Name. 

3. If needed, you can delete a recording by selecting the checkbox to the left of the name, and then clicking the Delete icon in the upper right corner of the screen.

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, the Recordings List in the Admin Portal has been enhanced to provide more options for instructors including making recordings private and uploading 3rd party transcripts.

Playback Rooms 

Learners can easily review class recordings in the Playback Room. Playback Rooms are open classrooms where learners can, independently or in a group of up to 10, access class content and engage with the material. Learners can review class recordings, participate in polls, ask and answer questions in the Q&A, take notes, and - if in a group - chat, talk, and learn together.

Using the same link for logging into the live class, learners select "Playback room" at the top of the screen. Click here to learn more.

How to Use Playback Rooms
25 days ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Playback Rooms are Engageli classrooms where all users can, independently or in a group of up to 10, access and engage with course content. Playback Rooms are open 24/7 and learners can use them for independent and group work without instructors or TAs.

Sitting around a virtual table, learners can gather to review class recordings, participate in polls, ask and answer questions in the Q&A, take notes, and chat, talk, and learn with other classmates. 

Engageli 3.1 and Engageli 3.0 will differ in appearance and some functionality. 

This article covers:

Accessing Playback Rooms
Playback Player & Class Recordings
Playback Room Features
Playback Room Settings
Invite Other Participants
Edit Class Recordings 
Upload External Videos and PDFs for Self-Paced Study [Engageli 3.0]
Complete Assignments [Engageli 3.1]
Playback Room Asynchronous Attendance
Use Cases: Using Playback Rooms
Accessing Playback Rooms

You can access all recordings directly from the same classroom link that you use for your live Engageli classes. You can also access Playback rooms from your Class Portal.
1. Open the classroom URL and select Playback room at the top of the screen.
2. Then, click Enter Playback room.

Playback Player & Class Recordings

Playback Rooms open to a view of the Playback Player and a list of class recordings. Choose a class recording or video to watch from the list, and then click the play video button in the middle of the playback player.[In Engageli 3.0, use the Select Recording drop-down menu.] Then, you can easily engage with the recording and material. You can:

Move through the video recording (play, pause, fast forward, back up).
Answer polls as they come up in a class recording.
Respond to class polls and view shared poll responses from the class.

Playback Room Features

In addition to watching class recordings and videos, you can

Take notes and review notes taken in the live class.
Ask and answer questions from class in the Q&A.
Share a screen.
Share a PDF. [Engageli 3.1 only]
Open a whiteboard for brainstorming, sketching, and diagramming.
Complete assigned Modules. [Engageli 3.1 only]
View the transcript of a class recording.
Use reactions and sounds.
Chat with other users in the Playback room.
Request help from instructors and TA(s). [Engageli 3.1 only]
View Self-Paced Materials (PDFs).

Playback Room Settings

Click Settings to open the Playback room settings:

Audio & Video - add a virtual background, blur your background, or change your audio output devices.
Display Captions - Display closed captions for audio.
Appearance - Change the platform interface language [Engageli 3.1 only] or theme color.

In Engageli 3.0, Click the More Actions (three dots) menu to open the Playback room settings.

Invite Other Participants

You can invite others to a Playback Room for supplemental instruction, office hours, tutoring, or whenever you want to review a class recording or class content with others. 

Click By Invitation [link icon] at the bottom right of the screen to get the invite link. [Click Invite & Info in older versions of Engageli 3.1.] You can make the room Open to allow any registered participant to join without an invite link. 

You can invite participants on the roster or guests who are not on the roster. By default, guest links are enabled for Playback Rooms. You can change that setting in the Admin Portal or within the live classroom. Click here to learn more.

As the host who started the group, you will retain the playback controls. That means you will control which class recording, video, or module assignment is selected for review. You can also mute and ask others to unmute as needed. To pass the playback controls to another participant:

1. Open the Gallery [Tablemates in Engageli 3.0] at the bottom of the screen.

2. Then click the three-dot menu in the person's video feed.

3. Click Make Host.

Edit Class Recordings 

Use Engageli to edit and trim class recordings to share the best version of the class with learners. Click here to learn more.

Upload External Videos and PDFs for Self-Paced Study [Engageli 3.0]

Instructors can upload external videos to the Admin Portal for learners to view in the Playback Room. This allows instructors to upload supplemental video content or instructional videos for flipped classroom models. Learners can engage with the video content the same way they do with the class recordings: take notes, annotate screenshots, post in the Q&A, collaborate, etc. 

Click here to learn how to upload a video for the Playback Room in the Admin Portal.

Instructors can add PDFs of presentations, readings, and other materials to the Playback Room. Learners can view the content in the Playback Room along with watching class recordings, reviewing notes taken in class, and responding to Q&A posts.

Click here to learn how to upload PDFs for the Playback Room in the Admin Portal.

Complete Assignments [Engageli 3.1]

Assignments allow instructors to easily and effectively author asynchronous experiences for their learners, such as adding course materials, documents and articles, self-paced polls (i.e., those not run during the live session), supplemental or additional recordings, and YouTube videos. 

1. Select Assignments from the bottom toolbar. Any assignments will appear in the right pane.

2. If the assignments have to be completed in order, assignments will be grayed out until you complete the task before. You will also have to complete the tasks in the order as assigned

3. If the assignments do not have to be completed in order, you can pick any assignment and tasks to complete.

4. When you finish all the tasks, the assignment will be marked complete.

Playback Room Asynchronous Attendance 

Engageli measures the percentage of class session time a participant attended each class session, whether synchronously or asynchronously in an Engageli Playback Room. Participants can receive attendance credit for watching class recordings in the Playback Room. 

Use Cases: Using Playback Rooms 

Peer-to-Peer Post-Class Learning

Learners can join a Playback Room to review the class recording and discuss a prompt posted in the Q&A tab. Learners can add questions and responses in the Q&A for the instructor to later review.
Instructors can direct learners to review a specific class recording that includes an in-class poll. Have the learners pause the video to discuss their responses to the poll question and summarize the group’s findings in the Q&A.

Flipped Classrooms

Instructors can use a Playback Room for flipped classroom instruction:
Learners can create study hall groups to engage with foundational material in the class recordings or posted in the Q&A to benefit from peer-to-peer learning.
They can also establish a foundation of key concepts before attending live sessions through interactive learning activities instructor-led group work and in-depth application of the subject matter.


Tutoring / Supplemental Instruction

TAs or a group leader can create a study hall session for tutoring/supplemental instruction, group office hour sessions, and exam preparation.

Group Project Work

Learners can work on group projects. The whiteboard and chat thread can be downloaded, and links to reference materials can be shared in the Q&A.

How to Set Up and Distribute Documents
2 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

You can distribute a shared document to the entire class or separate documents to each table so that learners can work collaboratively within the Engageli classroom.

Learners will be able to see and edit documents directly on the Engageli screen. This is great for brainstorming sessions, in-class group assignments, worksheets, or presentation preparation.

Note: This feature is best used for files that you want learners to edit together in class. If you wish to simply share notes, presentations, or other files with the class, it is best to upload the file in the Chat. A comprehensive guide on how to use the chat can be found here.

Class Document and Table Documents
Distribute Documents in Class
Prepare Shared Table Documents in the Admin Portal
Class Document and Table Documents

You distribute two kinds of documents in Engageli: a class document or table documents.

A class document is a file that opens for the entire class to view and edit directly on the Engageli screen.

When to use: You can use this feature to distribute a file to learners to collaborate in real-time for full class contributions/activities.

A table document is a file that opens for a particular table. You can have the same file open or different files for different tables.

When to use: You can use this feature to distribute a file to learners to collaborate in real-time on table-based activities, peer-to-peer instruction, station-based work, case studies per table, etc. You can distribute:
One document shared with all tables
Individual documents shared per table

For either a class document or separate table documents, you can share the following types of files:

Google Document, Sheet, and Slides
Microsoft 365 Word, Excel, and Powerpoint

Note: Microsoft 365 files open within Engageli in view-only mode. For editing, the files will open in a new tab.

Distribute Documents in Class

You can distribute documents in class without any prior setup.

1. Start your class.

2. When you are ready to distribute the documents, click the Present button at the bottom of the screen.

3. Select either Distribute Doc or Distribute Docs.

4. For a classroom doc, paste the link to the file you want to share and then click the Share button.

5. For table documents, select the set of files you want to share if you added them to the Admin Portal before class, or click the plus sign to add the links.

Note: You have to add links for each table, even if it’s the same file for each table.

Pro tip! Save time by adding table document links to the Admin Portal before class. Add them in the Materials section. At this time, shared class document links cannot be added beforehand, only shared table documents.

6. Learners will then see the document you have shared and be able to edit directly on the documents. 

You can change the links to be shared at any point during the class.

After enabling a shared doc, you will see a prompt to change the classroom audio to Table Mode.

7. When you are ready to collect the documents, click the Present button again, and then Stop. After clicking, learners will no longer be able to see or edit the document.

Prepare Shared Table Documents in the Admin Portal

1. Go to the Admin Portal.

2. Click Class Management on the left to expand the menu.

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class.

4. Click Materials.  

5. If you have sub-rooms created, click which room you want to add materials to, and then select the plus sign.

6. Give the set a name.

7. Select which type of files you want to share (G-Suite or Office 365).

8. Click Add.

9. Paste the shared links for the files you want to distribute in class. You can distribute one document per table. Learners seated at that table will be shown that document after activating the feature during class. 

10. Confirm that the linked documents are made editable for/by your class before distributing them. You should do this directly in the Google file or Microsoft 365 file that you plan to share.

 It's easy to record and share class recordings within Engageli so you and your learners can revisit class discussions, content, and material as needed!

Recording Settings (Pre-Class)

1. To access recording settings, go to the Admin Portal. 

2. Click Classes [Class Management in Engageli 3.0] on the left to expand the menu. 

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class. 

4. Click Details.

5. Select the Configuration tab.

6. Check Record learners' videos if you want to include in the class recordings the video feeds of learners who raise their hands to join the podium. If this option is unchecked, only the learners' audio will be captured in the recording.  

7. Check Auto start recording if you want the recording to automatically start after you log in and launch the classroom. This is helpful in case you forget to start the class recording.

Note: Settings will persist between class sessions. This means the setting(s) you selected most recently will be the default for future classes unless you change it. 

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, instructors and admins have options to record the Class Gallery and make the recording private by default.

 

Recording During Class 

1. Once the class has started, click the green dot (Record Lecture) to begin recording. Engageli 3.1 users click the Record button at the bottom of the screen. 

2. While recording, you can pause, stop, or continue the recording at any time.  

3. If you want to pause the recording, click the red dot (Stop Recording). Engageli 3.1 users click the Record button to pause. 

4. If/when you want to resume the recording, click the green dot (Record Lecture) again. Engageli 3.1 users click the Record button again to resume.

5. The recording will stop when class ends.

After class, a link to the recording will be emailed to the email address that you used to sign into Engageli. Each instructor listed on the roster will receive the email. The recording link is sent from a "do not reply" address, so if you don’t see it within five minutes to one hour, please check your Spam folder. 

Click here to learn which components are included in the class recording and ways you can optimize the recording for asynchronous learning in the Playback Room.

Recording Indicator 

When the class is being recorded, a red dot will appear in the top right corner of the instructor's video. Learners and instructors on the browser will see the following:

 

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, in addition to the red dot, all users will see and hear a notification whenever the recording starts or is paused.

Recordings After Class

After class, you can access recordings in the Admin Portal. 

1. Under your class, go to Recordings and you will see a list of all recordings.

2. You can easily change the name of the recordings by clicking the titles listed under Name. 

3. If needed, you can delete a recording by selecting the checkbox to the left of the name, and then clicking the Delete icon in the upper right corner of the screen.

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, the Recordings List in the Admin Portal has been enhanced to provide more options for instructors including making recordings private and uploading 3rd party transcripts.

Playback Rooms 

Learners can easily review class recordings in the Playback Room. Playback Rooms are open classrooms where learners can, independently or in a group of up to 10, access class content and engage with the material. Learners can review class recordings, participate in polls, ask and answer questions in the Q&A, take notes, and - if in a group - chat, talk, and learn together.

Using the same link for logging into the live class, learners select "Playback room" at the top of the screen. Click here to learn more.

Using Tables for Active Learning - Browser
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Engageli tables are strategically designed to increase collaboration between learners. Tables are built so learners will always be in small groups and you do not need to create breakout rooms for group activities. This allows you to create rich learning experiences at the tables while learners also feel simultaneously connected to the larger class and the instructor.

 

Joining Tables

Creating Random Tables Groups 

Moving learners to different Tables

 

Joining Tables

Joining tables allows you to leave the podium and “visit” groups of learners at tables, much like “walking the room” in an in-person class. This is great for any group work or discussions.

Instructions
1. To join a table, click the Tables tab.
2. Hover over the table that you'd like to join and click the JOIN button.

When you join the table, you will see, hear, and interact only with members of the table you joined. This is great when groups have a question on an in-class assignment and you don't want to interrupt the entire class.

3. When you are ready to leave the table, click the Back to podium button. Engageli 3.1 users have several options for returning to the podium.

Note: The audio will automatically switch from Room Mode to Table Mode. When you leave the table, you will have to switch the audio setting back to Room Mode to enable a full-class discussion. Click to learn more about the audio settings.

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, instructors will peek at or observe tables unobtrusively without disturbing the learners. 

 
Creating Random Tables Groups 

This is a great way to encourage learner engagement is to randomly arrange table groups for discussions. 

Instructions

1. Go to the Seating Arrangement drop-down menu in the Tables view. 

2. Select Random Arrangement Table Size.

3. Choose the number of learners you would like at each table. The system will automatically break learners into randomized groups.

You can also reserve any of the first 3 tables for staff or other participants who you don't want to move during the random arrangement. In Engageli 3.0, this is called Skip Tables.

Note: If learners have a reservation, then they will be treated as learners. Make sure to remove any reservations before you do this! (See instructions on reservations here).

You can save the table arrangement you created as a preset that you can use again. Click for information on how to create a table preset during a class.

 

Moving Learners to Different Tables 

Instructions
1. Navigate to the Tables view.
2. Click the profile icon of the learner you wish to move.

3. Choose a new table for the learner from the drop-down menu.

4. Or, you can simply drag and drop the learner to a different table.

How to Track Learner Engagement During Class - Instructor Application
9 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone
  Note: This article is for the Instructor application only. Browser-based instructors should click here for instructions.
There are many ways to track engagement in Engageli, for individual learners as well as the entire class. These markers can help you keep a pulse on how the class is engaging with and learning the content so you can adjust as needed.

 

Class Engagement

Individual Engagement Markers

 

Class Engagement

(Note: At this time, class markers are only available if you are teaching on the instructor application.)

 

1. Emojis: The Emoji Thermometer measures learner sentiment. Learners have four emoji options: red, orange, yellow, and green. As learners answer, the thermometer will move up and down. All answers are anonymous, so you will get the aggregate of the responses. 

Some example questions to use with Emojis are:

"How are you feeling today?"
"How confident are you in the material we just covered?"

2. The Bowtie Thermometer measures aggregate class engagement. As learners interact with the platform, the engagement bar will move up and down. 

Examples of platform engagement are: raising hands, chatting, asking questions in Q&A, answering polls/quizzes, giving thumbs up or down, etc.

 

Individual Engagement Markers

In addition to tracking full class engagement with the engagement thermometers, you can also track individual learner engagement.

 

1. Thumbs up/thumbs down: You can ask learners to give you a thumbs up or down. Everyone will see the thumbs appear instantly on the screen, but only instructors and TAs will see individual thumbs up/thumbs down on the learners' video feeds in the Class Gallery.

Thumbs up or down can be used to get quick feedback, check understanding, or check if learners are paying attention. Some example questions to use with thumbs are:

"Do you understand the material we just covered?"
"Give me a thumbs up if you can see my screen."

Pro Tip! Use thumbs up or down to check engagement for learners with their cameras off. When coming back after a break, if many learners turned off their cameras, ask for a thumbs up if learners are back and then look at the class gallery to see how many thumbs up there are.

  Engageli 3.0 
In Engageli 3.0, there are new reactions and sounds for learners and instructors. Click here to learn more.

2. Green Dot marker

Each learner has an engagement marker next to their video feed on the gallery view of the instructor application.

 

The green dot marker represents when a learner is "active," meaning that they have recently interacted in the classroom in some way. The green dot resets to the maximum size (5) each time a learner does one of the following:

Writes a question or answer in Q&A
Responds to a poll question
Raises a hand
Shares screen with their table
Shares screen with their class
Uses thumbs up/down
Uses emojis
Initiates audio activity (speaking, unmuting microphone)

Note: The green marker decays and appears smaller after some time. The decay is linear, from maximum (5) to minimum (0) over three minutes. Hovering over the indicator in a learner’s video feed shows an engagement value out of 5 (Engagement - 5/5). Any form of activity listed above will turn the marker green.

The gray dot marker replaces the green markers when a learner who was previously active has not recently interacted in the classroom. In general, a green marker will turn gray after three minutes. The gray marker corresponds to an Engagement rating of 0/5.
No marker simply means the learner has not interacted in the classroom at any point.
The perforated (dotted) marker indicates that a learner who was seated at a table has left the class. They are still represented in the class by what's called a reservation, as explained in this article.

You can also see the green dot marker in the LISTS view.

 

3. Table Engagement

In addition to the learner’s video feed and LISTS view, the individual engagement markers trigger an engagement indication at the table level, which you can see in the TABLES view.

Similar to the green dot marker, the green table ring decays and fades away after some time due to inactivity. The decay is linear, from maximum (5) to minimum (0) over three minutes.

Class session recordings are automatically uploaded to the Playback Room shortly after the session ends. Instructors can upload external videos to the Admin Portal for learners to view in the Playback Room. This allows instructors to upload supplemental video content or instructional videos for flipped classroom models. Learners can engage with the video content the same way they do with the class recordings: take notes, annotate screenshots, post in the Q&A, collaborate, etc.

Instructions

1. Go to the Admin Portal.

2. Click Class Management on the left to expand the menu. 

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class.

How to Use the Notes
2 months ago Updated
Follow

Taking notes can make it difficult to stay engaged and follow along with a class presentation or discussion. With Engageli’s Notes feature, you can:

Take screenshots of what is being shared via screen share, PDF file live share, or whiteboards
Annotate the screenshots to reduce the cognitive load with note taking.*

Note: No one can take screenshots of the Class Gallery or Table view, to protect learner privacy.

Engageli learners always have access to the Notes feature in the live session and in the Playback Room. Browser-based instructors can also take notes. The Notes are private, downloadable for future reference, and persist between live sessions and the Playback Room, so you will see them each time you log into an Engageli classroom or Playback Room to watch recordings.

Instructions

1. To take notes, select the Notes icon at the bottom of the screen.

2. Type in the Start typing field, and then either hit return or enter on your keyboard or click the send icon to add your note.

3. Click the camera icon to take a screenshot of a shared screen or presentation. 

4. Hit Click to annotate to highlight, add text, or other notations to the screenshot.

5. Click Save & Close to save your annotations.

6. Click the download icon to export your notes as a .docx file. 

Notes:

A timestamp is displayed next to each note taken so you can easily find your place when later watching class recordings.  

You can delete entries by clicking the trash bin icon to the right of the notes.

 

*Flanigan, A. E., & Titsworth, S. (2020). The impact of digital distraction on lecture note taking and student learning. Instructional Science, 48(5), 495-524.

How to Track Learner Engagement During Class
1 month ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

There are many ways to track engagement in Engageli. These markers can help you keep a pulse on how the class is engaging with and learning the content so you can adjust as needed.

 

Individual Engagement Markers

1. Thumbs up/thumbs down

You can ask learners to use the reactions to give you a thumbs up or down. Everyone will see the thumbs appear instantly on the screen, but only instructors and TAs will see individual thumbs up/thumbs down on the learners' video feeds in the Class Gallery.

Thumbs up or down can be used to get quick feedback, check understanding, or check if learners are paying attention. Some example questions to use with thumbs are:

"Do you understand the material we just covered?"
"Give me a thumbs up if you can see my screen."

Pro Tip! Use thumbs up or down to check engagement for learners with their cameras off. When coming back after a break, if many learners turned off their cameras, ask for a thumbs up if learners are back and then look at the class gallery to see how many thumbs up there are.

There are additional reactions and sounds for learners and instructors. Click here to learn more. 

2. Green Dot Marker

Each learner has an engagement marker in the bottom right corner of their video feed in the Class Gallery.

The green dot marker represents when a learner is "active," meaning that they have recently interacted in the classroom in some way. The green dot resets to the maximum size (5) each time a learner does one of the following:

Writes a question or answer in Q&A
Responds to a poll question
Raises hand
Lowers hand
Shares screen with their table
Shares screen with their class
Uses thumbs up/down
Uses other emojis reactions
Sends a chat message (private chats are not included)
Initiates audio activity (speaking, unmuting microphone)

Note: The green marker decays and appears smaller after some time. The decay is linear, from maximum (5) to minimum (0) over three minutes. Hovering over the indicator in a learner’s video feed shows an engagement value out of 5 (Engagement - 5/5). Any form of activity listed above will turn the marker green.

The gray dot marker replaces the green markers when a learner who was previously active has not recently interacted in the classroom. In general, a green marker will turn gray after three minutes. The gray marker corresponds to an Engagement rating of 0/5.

No marker simply means the learner has not interacted in the classroom at any point.

The perforated (dotted) marker indicates that a learner who was seated at a table has left the class. They are still represented in the class by what's called a reservation, as explained in this article.

You can also see the green dot marker next to the learner's name in the List view in the Tables tab.

 

Table Engagement

In addition to the learner’s video feed and the Lists view, the individual engagement markers trigger an engagement indication at the table level, which you can see in the Tables tab at the top of the screen.

Similar to the green dot marker, the green table ring decays and fades away after some time due to inactivity. The decay is linear, from maximum (5) to minimum (0) over three minutes.

Join each table and take a screenshot of the whiteboard in your Notes.

Ask one learner from each table to download the whiteboard and upload the screenshot to the Chat.

Ask one learner from each table to screen share their whiteboard with the entire class, and then take a screenshot in your Notes.

Engageli Tables Overview - Instructor Application
9 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone
  Note: This article is for the Instructor application only. Browser-based instructors should click here for instructions.
Engageli tables are strategically designed to increase collaboration between learners. Tables are built so learners will always be in small groups so there is no need to create breakout rooms for activities. This allows you to create rich learning experiences at the tables, while learners also feel simultaneously connected to the larger class and the instructor.

 

Add Tables
	
Rename Tables


Change the Number of Seats at Tables
	
Remove Table Reservations

 

Add Tables

An Engageli classroom opens with 5 tables, each with 10 seats, by default. As the tables fill with learners, more tables are added automatically. However, you can manually add tables 5 at a time with no more than 40 recommended.

Instructions

1. Navigate to the Tables view.

2. Click the Actions menu.

3. Select Add 5 tables.

NOTE: At this time, you cannot remove tables that have been added to the classroom.

 
Rename Tables

You can easily rename the tables in your Engageli classroom. Table names can mirror the instructional model and range from project group names, book characters, or course topics to fun names based on hobbies or interests.

Instructions

During Class

1. Go to the TABLES view.

2. Hover over the table you want to rename.

3. Click the existing name of the table.

4. Enter the new name.

5. Click the table to save the change.

6. You will see a confirmation notification at the top of the screen.

Note: The new table names will be saved and persist in the Admin Portal and the next time you log into the classroom.

Admin Portal

1. Go to the Admin Portal.

2. Click Class Management on the left to expand the menu. 

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class. 

4. Click Tables & Preset.

5. Select the row for the table.

6. Enter the new table name.

7. Press Return or Enter on your computer.

8. You will see a confirmation notification at the bottom of the screen.

 

Change the Number of Seats at Tables

By default, an Engageli classroom opens with the maximum number of seats allowed at a table: 10. As an instructor, you can easily change the number of seats at a table.  

Engageli classroom with 10 seats per table

 

Instructions

1. Click the gear icon to open the settings.

2. Select Classroom Configuration.

3. Use the slider to select the number of seats for the tables.

4. Click the Close button. The changes will be applied immediately.

Pro Tip! When deciding the number of seats, keep in mind that if you have multiple TAs who will visit tables, an available empty seat will be needed. Instructors, co-instructors, and one TA can visit tables without needing an empty seat.

Engageli classroom with 5 seats per table

 

Remove Table Reservations

Table reservations ensure that a learner can keep their spot at a table should they lose their internet connection and get logged out of the classroom. When the learner re-joins the classroom, they will automatically be placed at the same table as before. Because of having an assigned seat at the table, a table of seven present learners and three reserved is considered full.

You may want to remove table reservations to free up space at certain tables or create random table groups without including reservations in the count.

Within Tables view, you can see all reservations represented by a dotted line around a learner’s profile icon.

 

Instructions

1. Go to the TABLES view.

2. In the drop-down menu Action, select Remove All Reservations. 

3. You can remove an individual reservation by clicking on the learner's icon at the table and then removing it. 

Note: Individual reservations will be automatically removed after 5 minutes of inactivity.

How to Record and Share Class Recordings
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

 It's easy to record and share class recordings within Engageli so you and your learners can revisit class discussions, content, and material as needed!

Recording Settings (Pre-Class)

1. To access recording settings, go to the Admin Portal. 

2. Click Classes [Class Management in Engageli 3.0] on the left to expand the menu. 

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class. 

4. Click Details.

5. Select the Configuration tab.

6. Check Record learners' videos if you want to include in the class recordings the video feeds of learners who raise their hands to join the podium. If this option is unchecked, only the learners' audio will be captured in the recording.  

7. Check Auto start recording if you want the recording to automatically start after you log in and launch the classroom. This is helpful in case you forget to start the class recording.

Note: Settings will persist between class sessions. This means the setting(s) you selected most recently will be the default for future classes unless you change it. 

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, instructors and admins have options to record the Class Gallery and make the recording private by default.

 

Recording During Class 

1. Once the class has started, click the green dot (Record Lecture) to begin recording. Engageli 3.1 users click the Record button at the bottom of the screen. 

2. While recording, you can pause, stop, or continue the recording at any time.  

3. If you want to pause the recording, click the red dot (Stop Recording). Engageli 3.1 users click the Record button to pause. 

4. If/when you want to resume the recording, click the green dot (Record Lecture) again. Engageli 3.1 users click the Record button again to resume.

5. The recording will stop when class ends.

After class, a link to the recording will be emailed to the email address that you used to sign into Engageli. Each instructor listed on the roster will receive the email. The recording link is sent from a "do not reply" address, so if you don’t see it within five minutes to one hour, please check your Spam folder. 

Click here to learn which components are included in the class recording and ways you can optimize the recording for asynchronous learning in the Playback Room.

Recording Indicator 

When the class is being recorded, a red dot will appear in the top right corner of the instructor's video. Learners and instructors on the browser will see the following:

 

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, in addition to the red dot, all users will see and hear a notification whenever the recording starts or is paused.

Recordings After Class

After class, you can access recordings in the Admin Portal. 

1. Under your class, go to Recordings and you will see a list of all recordings.

2. You can easily change the name of the recordings by clicking the titles listed under Name. 

3. If needed, you can delete a recording by selecting the checkbox to the left of the name, and then clicking the Delete icon in the upper right corner of the screen.

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, the Recordings List in the Admin Portal has been enhanced to provide more options for instructors including making recordings private and uploading 3rd party transcripts.

Playback Rooms 

Learners can easily review class recordings in the Playback Room. Playback Rooms are open classrooms where learners can, independently or in a group of up to 10, access class content and engage with the material. Learners can review class recordings, participate in polls, ask and answer questions in the Q&A, take notes, and - if in a group - chat, talk, and learn together.

Using the same link for logging into the live class, learners select "Playback room" at the top of the screen. Click here to learn more.

The following are updates to the Jan 7, 2022 release notes. 

Engageli now has two main audio modes, Room Mode and Table Mode. 

Room Mode:

This is the default mode when entering an Engageli classroom.
An instructor can hear all learners.
All learners can hear each other, regardless of what table they are seated at.

When used: the beginning of class, or entire classroom discussions

Table Mode:

An instructor only hears learners who have their hands raised. 
Learners can only hear their tablemates or those with their hands raised.
If an instructor or co-instructor joins a table, Engageli automatically switches to Table Mode. 
If an instructor joins a table, only the learners at that table will hear them and the instructor only hears the learners at that table.
To hear all tables concurrently,  an instructor can choose “Hear tables while on podium in table mode” from the menu options.

When used: small group discussions, activities, group projects

This video demonstrates how to add multiple Engageli classes to one Canvas course. 

Deep Linking is an extension to LTI that allows data to be passed back to the Learning Management System, Canvas, in the context of an LTI launch of an online learning platform such as Engageli. With the inclusion of this extension, institutions can leverage Deep Linking to provide a seamless launch experience between Canvas and Engageli.

 

If you've created Course A in Canvas and want to link it to Course B and Course C, you'll need to launch Course A from Canvas as an instructor via the Engageli link before linking. Once you've launched Course A as an instructor it will create the course in Engageli and then you'll have the option to link to it when you create Course B and Course C.

 

Use Case

The Deep Linking extension allows an institution to link one Canvas course to multiple Engageli classrooms, keeping data analytics intact. For example, this allows one Canvas course to link to separate Engageli classrooms, one for live sessions and one for group collaboration.

Camera Issues - PC
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

 

Camera issues can happen for a number of reasons. First, check that your camera is on and that you've granted camera permissions.

If that doesn't work, we're here to help!

Click here if you use a Mac. 

 

Granting Camera Permission during Class 

Granting Camera Permission from Browser

Granting Camera Permission from Computer

Is an Anti-Virus Disabling Your Camera?

 

 

Checking Your Camera During Class 

1. Make sure the camera image indicates that your camera is on. If the camera icon is red, then your camera is off.

 

2. Check that you have connected the correct camera to the Engageli classroom through Settings (gear icon).

 

Granting Permission to Use Camera from Browser

 

Google Chrome

1. Click "Allow" on the pop-up permission prompt when you first log into your class. 

 

2. If you do not see this option, click on the lock icon in the top left corner of your screen next to your address bar. Make sure the camera is toggled to "Allow."

 

 

Edge

1. Click"Allow" on the pop-up permission prompters when you first log into your class.

 

2. If this is not an option, click on the lock icon in the top left corner of your screen next to your address bar. Ensure from this menu that your camera is set to "Allow."





 

Granting Permission to Use Camera from Computer (PC)

 

1. Go to your system settings, which you can find by searching "settings" in your finder.

 

 

2. Next, click on "Privacy" from the resulting menu.

 

3. Click "Camera" from the privacy menu.

4. Make sure that your camera is allowed on your device (which is the default), and that "Allow apps to access your camera" is toggled on.

 

 

5. Next, scroll down to "Allow desktop apps to access your camera," and ensure that this is toggled on. You should see Engageli on this list.

 

 

 

Is an Anti Virus Disabling Your Camera?

If none of the above steps solve the camera issue, it is possible that an anti-virus application is disabling your camera. The Kaspersky Anti-Virus software is most commonly seen.

Windows

1. Go to the taskbar and search for the application "Kapersky Internet Security."

2. Navigate to "Privacy Protection" and click on "Webcam Protection." 

 

3. Clicking on the link will reveal checkable boxes. Be sure that "Block access to webcam for all applications" is not marked with a check.

 

4. You can then restart your computer and try using your webcam again.
