Release notes for August 28, 2023

These notes provide information about the release of Engageli 3.1.34 including new and enhanced features, improvements and resolved issues.

Engageli 3.1 takes the best of Engageli to a new level with a focus on stability and ease-of-use. Based on feedback from partners, we've improved the Engageli classroom to better support teaching and active learning and provide a flexible learning environment for all participants. In addition to a variety of new features, Engageli’s team has enhanced the overall teaching and learning experience in many ways. 

Exciting New Features
Dial-in support (Beta)
For U.S. customers only
Learners without access to a computer or mobile app can dial into the classroom.
Lock Tables 
Instructors can lock tables to stop learners from moving between tables to better manage their learners and class activities.
Peek at Tables
Instructors can now observe table activities unobtrusively without interrupting the learners.
Two Instructors Using Web Browsers
Two users on web browsers can act as instructors, as opposed to needing the instructor application as in previous versions.
Collaboration Spaces
New Playback Room features allow for collaboration spaces where learners can review course material and complete assignments and supplemental material in groups.
Self-Paced Assignments
Engageli’s self-paced materials have been enhanced to allow completion tracking and customized tasks that can be completed individually or in groups.
More New Features and Enhancements

Accessibility

Users with the TA or instructor role can provide manual captions. 
Instructors can manually replace transcribed captioning files. Learners with accommodation may need additional help via transcription in the Playback Room. If the institution uses third-party transcription services, these files can be used within Engageli. 

Localization and Language Compatibility

Users can change the application UI language (English, French, Spanish, or Japanese). 
Some English remains (e.g. End User Terms of Use)
Instructors can change the language detection for closed captions.
Chinese (China), Australian English, British English, American English, French (France), Canadian French, German (Germany), Hindi (India), Italian (Italy), Japanese (Japan), Korean (South Korea), Brazilian Portuguese, Spanish (United States), Thai (Thailand)

Asynchronous Experience/Playback Rooms

Users can mark their Playback Rooms as public or private. Public Playback Rooms allow any user online to join.
Users can request help from within the Playback Room and an alert is sent to the instructor.
Instructors can enable email notifications to instructors, TAs, or both for new questions posted in the Playback Room Q&A.
Playback Room users who invite others (the Host) can mute and request to unmute the other participants.
Users can use the PDF Share to display documents in the Playback Room.
Users can message an AI Assistant in the Chat for basic queries. (English only)
Users can create permanent links to share to meet in the same Playback Room on different occasions.
Users can easily find class recordings with the newly designed Playback Room UI that provides a visual representation of recordings.
New for Instructors, TAs, and Learners

Advanced Controls

New option to make classes accessible to learners only when the instructor who is logged in enables it. Other restrictions: 
Disallow anonymous chat
Disallow anonymous Q&A
Disallow file uploads to the chat and whiteboard
Filter to disallow inappropriate messages in the chat & Q&A (English only)
Class recordings are set to private by default 

Audio Experience

Noise reduction setting that uses machine learning-based technology to distinguish human speech from background noises for an enhanced audio experience.
Hybrid Meetings
Audio settings to maximize the user experience in multi-location synchronous settings. For example, if three learners are sitting together in the same location all logged into their Engageli virtual live session.
Table mode is not supported.

Class Recordings

Table whiteboards are included in class recordings viewed in an Engageli Playback Room.
The PDF live share quality is improved in class recordings.
Instructors have the option to make recordings private by default rather than immediately have them available in the Playback Room. Instructors can make edits if needed and later publish the recordings to the Playback Room for learner access. 
The Class Gallery can be included in the class recording.
Highlighted tabs in the live session indicate to the instructor what is being recorded.
Screen share and PDF share annotations are included in the class recordings to improve the viewing experience for asynchronous learners.

Chat, Notes, Q&A

Instructors can turn on AI-powered chat functionality to detect and block inappropriate messages to maintain safe learning environments on Engageli. (English only at this time.)  
Anonymous chats can be disabled by instructors in the class configurations.

Class Gallery

Users can turn on “Auto Rotate Gallery” to see users on all pages of the gallery easily.
Users have new ways to sort the class gallery: Recent Speakers, Camera on, Table seating, and Names (first name, alphabetically).
Users can open the Class Gallery in the right side panel.
Learners only see the Class Gallery in Room Mode. In Table Mode, learners see the Tablemates Gallery. 
Users can search the Class Gallery by Active and Not Active (not present) participants.
Learners can deselect “My Video First” in the Sort gallery options. If deselected, the user’s video will no longer appear in the top left position of the gallery, to reduce virtual classroom fatigue.

In-class Teaching Tools

Polls 
Text input (word cloud) poll answers are shown on user video feeds in the Class Gallery so instructors can easily see each learner’s response.
Improved UI for creating table arrangements based on poll responses. 
Screen Share
Instructors and TAs see an improved UI when learner screen share approval is needed.
For Mac users, a new permissions page that includes screen share permissions is prompted at login to avoid screen share issues. 
Staff and learners can annotate a screen share to provide visualization or highlight important concepts during instruction or class discussions. 
PDF Share
Staff and learners can annotate a shared PDF. 
Users can navigate directly to a specific page in a shared PDF.
Whiteboards
Users can upload or drag & drop image files to display on Engageli whiteboards. 
Simplified setting to restrict editing to only staff. 
Tables
Instructors can use table presets during free seating.
The Seating Arrangement drop-down menu has been updated for better usability.
Instructors can adjust settings to open the classroom in Table Mode. 
Improved UI for creating random table arrangements. 

Login Simplification 

All users have the same login link (instructors, learners, TAs).
The login screen UI and flow have been improved for ease of use.
Staff and learners now have a “My Class Portal,” personalized landing pages for easy access to classrooms, Playback Rooms, assignments, and class recordings. [Not available with LTI integrations]

Podium

Instructors can hide their video to allow for a producer mode with one instructor facilitating the session out of learner view.
Instructors can go back to the podium after visiting tables more easily with the “Leave” icon on the instructor video.
Instructors can enable meeting mode to disable the fixed podium to create a working space for meetings or sessions without an instructor presence at the “front” of the classroom. 

Notifications

Audio notification (English) when the recording starts or is paused. 
Notification for instructors and learners when the instructor directs the class to a different view.
Improved notification when an instructor might replace an existing instructor in a live classroom. 

User Experience/User Interface

Users can double-click on a screen share to display it in full-screen mode.
Visual display of speakers who are not on the podium when the class is in Room Mode.
Improved UI for staff and learner controls and settings with updated visual icons and written descriptions. 
Product version number listed in the media settings. 
Administrators

Admin Portal

New section for Administrators called Class Management. Classes can be deleted or archived in bulk. 
Individual class management is now called Classes. 
New additional site-wide privacy, security, and Playback Room-related settings.
New settings allow administrators to customize virtual background options as well as upload custom background images.
Instructors and administrators can generate links for shared Google docs for multiple tables to save time copying/pasting links.
Instructors and admins can add links for shared class documents, MS 365 or Google, so they are already available in the live class. 
New tabs to make the classroom & Playback Room settings easier to find: 
Common configuration
Live configuration
Playback configuration 
The 15-minute Class Timeout setting can be disabled.
New option to enable short token format class URLs. 
Attendance data is generated for a class without a specified schedule that lasts at least 15 minutes. 
New button to open the instructor My Class portal from the Admin Portal. 
New button to Download all chat from the Admin Portal. 
New link to Live Configuration page to update attendance settings.
The “Self-paced polls” section of Classes is changed to “Async Polls”
The Attendance Analytics now includes a filter for Combined attendance for attending a live session and viewing a recording in a Playback Room. 

Infrastructure

Media-related auto-scaling improvements.
Support for 3000 concurrent learners on a sandbox.
Support for larger classes (600 learners in a class and more per prior agreement).

Integrations

New admin settings to hide instructor app or Admin Portal LTI link placement from the deep linking selector.
New LTI integration to enable instructors or admins to insert specific Playback Room Recordings and Assignment links to an LMS course.
Notification improvements in the login flow to direct learners back to their LMS.

This is no longer necessary as any user can be temporarily elevated to the instructor role.

How to use PowerPoint Presenter View and see Slide Notes on a Single Monitor - Mac
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

This article will show you how to share a PowerPoint presentation in Engageli, use the Presenter View, and see your presentation notes. 

Click here for instructions if you are using a PC.

Quick Overview

Instructions

Make sure you are logged into your Engageli classroom.
Open your PowerPoint Presentation. 
Click the SlideShow icon on the bottom right to start the slide show. 
Your slide show will open up in full screen on your single monitor.
Hover near the bottom left of the screen. 
Click the three dots menu.
Select Show Presenter View. 
The Presenter View opens in a separate window. 
To get back to your Engageli classroom, you can use your Mac's Mission Control feature to see all the windows that you have open.
There are four ways to open Mission Control:
Swipe up with three or four fingers on your trackpad
Double-tap the surface of your Apple mouse with two fingers.
Open the Mission Control app in your Applications folder.
Press the Mission Control key  on your Apple keyboard or Touch Bar.
When you see all the windows you have open, select the browser window with your Engageli classroom. 
Once back in the Engageli classroom, click the Present button at the bottom of the screen.

Under Classroom activities, click Screen Share.

Click Window.

Select the preview image of the window you want to share. Select the image of the presentation slide show. A border will highlight the image and the Share button will become enabled.
Click Share. 
Your view will go back to the slide show. 
To get back to the Presenter View, use Mission Control to see your open windows.
Select the Presenter View window. 
Use the forward and back arrows to navigate your presentation. 

Pro Tip! Remember to use Mission Control to see all your open windows.

  Note: For Mac users, it might be easier to share presentations in Google Slides. Click here to learn more about sharing presentations and viewing speaker notes in Google Slides on Engageli.

If you can't enter your classroom after logging in with your email address and password, use these instructions to troubleshoot.

If your institution or company uses a learning management system (i.e., Moodle, Canvas, etc.) you may not be able to log in with a direct link by design. For example, if your institution has a web portal that has all of your classes; log in to that portal, find the class link and open it from there. Copy/pasting the link or accessing it from a bookmark won’t allow you to properly authenticate! 

Instructions

1. Open a new Chrome incognito or Edge in a private window.

2. Copy the classroom URL, and then paste it into the URL address bar of the browser window.

3. Press enter or return on your computer.

4 Click the Sign in button to log in using the credentials associated with your class account.

5. If the issue persists and you are redirected back to the login screen, try logging in with a different email address. This could be due to your email address not being on the class roster or a mismatch between the email address being entered and the email address listed on the class roster.

6. Reach out to our Support team!

Engageli polls are great for icebreaker activities, checking concept understanding, breakout discussions, or collaboration with tables. 

 

Creating a Poll or Quiz

Running a Poll or Quiz in Class

1. To start a quiz or poll, first make sure that you are in your Engageli classroom.

2. Share your screen with the document containing the quiz or poll you want to run.

3. Click the Scan button [Activate Tag (QR Code) in Engageli 3.0] button to start the poll or quiz. 

Engageli 3.1

Engageli 3.0

 





Sharing Poll or Quiz Results

1. You can share the results with your class by using the Share Results toggle. This allows learners to see the total number of selections for each answer choice. You can also see the number of learners who answered and did not answer the poll question. This is will not appear to learners when you share the results.


Pro Tip! Use poll responses to group learners for discussion. You can ask learners to move to a specific table based on their answer or you can randomly assign tables and have them discuss which answer they chose and why.  

Share the Correct Answer to a Poll or Quiz 

If your poll or quiz has a correct answer that you would like to share with the learners, you can click the specific option(s) in your screen share. The correct answer(s) will display a check mark when you share the results of the poll or quiz.

 

Locking the Poll or Quiz

1. Selecting Lock Answers will prevent learners from submitting additional responses or changing responses.

Pro Tip! Locking can be useful for conducting timed polls and quizzes as well as preventing learners from changing their responses while sharing results with the class.

 

Ending the Poll or Quiz

1. To stop the poll or quiz, click the Scan button [Activate Tag in Engageli 3.0] button again or click the Stop Poll button in the top right corner of the screen. 

Viewing Learner Poll Response in the Class Gallery

While you're running the poll or quiz, you can view the learners' individual final poll responses displayed on their video feeds in the Class Gallery. Once you stop the poll or move to the next screen in your presentation, the green or gray dot engagement marker will return to the learners' video feeds. Under My View, change your view to the Class Gallery to see the responses.

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, instructors can see learner responses to text poll questions on their video feeds in the Class Gallery.

Camera Issues - PC
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

 

Camera issues can happen for a number of reasons. First, check that your camera is on and that you've granted camera permissions.

If that doesn't work, we're here to help!

Click here if you use a Mac. 

 

Granting Camera Permission during Class 

Granting Camera Permission from Browser

Granting Camera Permission from Computer

Is an Anti-Virus Disabling Your Camera?

 

 

Checking Your Camera During Class 

1. Make sure the camera image indicates that your camera is on. If the camera icon is red, then your camera is off.

 

2. Check that you have connected the correct camera to the Engageli classroom through Settings (gear icon).

 

Granting Permission to Use Camera from Browser

 

Google Chrome

1. Click "Allow" on the pop-up permission prompt when you first log into your class. 

 

2. If you do not see this option, click on the lock icon in the top left corner of your screen next to your address bar. Make sure the camera is toggled to "Allow."

 

 

Edge

1. Click"Allow" on the pop-up permission prompters when you first log into your class.

 

2. If this is not an option, click on the lock icon in the top left corner of your screen next to your address bar. Ensure from this menu that your camera is set to "Allow."





 

Granting Permission to Use Camera from Computer (PC)

 

1. Go to your system settings, which you can find by searching "settings" in your finder.

 

 

2. Next, click on "Privacy" from the resulting menu.

 

3. Click "Camera" from the privacy menu.

4. Make sure that your camera is allowed on your device (which is the default), and that "Allow apps to access your camera" is toggled on.

 

 

5. Next, scroll down to "Allow desktop apps to access your camera," and ensure that this is toggled on. You should see Engageli on this list.

 

 

 

Is an Anti Virus Disabling Your Camera?

If none of the above steps solve the camera issue, it is possible that an anti-virus application is disabling your camera. The Kaspersky Anti-Virus software is most commonly seen.

Windows

1. Go to the taskbar and search for the application "Kapersky Internet Security."

2. Navigate to "Privacy Protection" and click on "Webcam Protection." 

 

3. Clicking on the link will reveal checkable boxes. Be sure that "Block access to webcam for all applications" is not marked with a check.

 

4. You can then restart your computer and try using your webcam again.

How to Control Closed Captions for a Class
2 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Closed captions must be enabled at an organization level prior to enabling captions for each individual classroom. For more information about how to check if your organization has captions enabled, see this article. 

Once closed captions have been enabled at an organization level, each classroom will have captions set to off by default. Classes that had closed captions enabled prior to version 3.0.58 will need to have this feature enabled on a per classroom basis. 

Go to the Admin Portal.
Click Classes (Class Management in v3.0) from the menu on the Left.
Select your class from the list of Active Classes or use the search field to find your class.

Click the class name.
Select Details.
Click the Live Configuration tab (Configuration tab in v3.0).
Click the Checkbox next to Captions during live session to adjust.
We also offer the option to create a caption .vtt file which contains the audio transcript and timestamps for playback rooms.
To enable this feature, click the Checkbox next to Create caption vtt file when recording.
Captions must be enabled in the classroom for them to also show up in the playback room.
Click Save changes.
Once closed captions have been enabled for a classroom the instructor will need to turn on the feature for each session. For more information, see this article.

 Need more help? Contact Support.

How to setup Classroom Attendance Passback
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Attendance pass back is defined as the Engageli platform’s integration to a learning management system that is used to send attendance information on a per class scheduled session basis.

In the Site Management section of our admin panel, Super Admins can access the LMS configuration panel which controls attendance pass back settings at a global level for all classes. Once items have been set in this panel, all new classes will inherit those settings including two values that can be “locked”.

Before you set up Attendance Passback you must ensure that your class schedule has been assigned in the Scheduler. For more information on how to schedule your class, see this article.

How to access Classroom LMS configuration settings

Visit the Admin portal (version 3.0.43+).

Click Classes (Class Management in v3.0) on the left side.

If you don’t see this menu, click the 3 lines (hamburger) in the top left of the window to expand.

Search for the class you’d like to adjust and select it.

Click on Details and select the Live Configuration (Configuration in v3.0) tab on the right side of the window.

First we’ll set up the LMS Configuration settings which can be found in the bottom left.

Select your Session Ratio by entering or picking a value in the drop down menu.

This is a threshold (percentage) of class time that instructors are required to be logged into the class. The full duration of the class must be set via the Scheduler and this schedule is used to calculate occupancy. Once the instructor has occupied the class within the scheduled timeframe and meets the threshold, the session will be considered valid. By default, this value is set to 50%.

Select your Attendance Ratio by entering or picking a value in the drop down menu.

This is the threshold (percentage) of a session that a participant must attend to be considered present in the class. By default, this value is set to 60%.

Enable or Disable Skip roster sync with LMS (by default this setting is unchecked) by checking or unchecking the box. Note: We do not recommend adjusting this setting without consulting your Solutions Engineer.

Roster sync will automatically sync an entire class roster to Engageli every time an instructor logs into the class via LTI. This checkbox allows administrators to disable/enable this feature.

When this feature is turned off, an individual user’s LMS roster information will be synced each time they login via LTI.

If the person is no longer in the LMS class but present in our class roster, they will remain in the roster but be marked “inactive” and will NOT have access to the class.

Enable or Disable Upload class attendance to LMS by checking or unchecking the box. Note: This field can be locked by an administrator to disable others to control this setting at a class level. If you are not able to adjust this setting, please reach out to your administrator.

When enabled, this feature will upload attendance to the integrated LMS as a course grade item.

Once enabled, class attendance will be synced at regular intervals set in LTI site settings, for more information this setting please see this article. Additionally, this allows attendance to be manually synced by instructors at the class level.

Set LMS attendance maximum score by picking an option from the drop down menu.

This sets the maximum attendance score possible for a participant that will be passed back to your LMS. There are two options for maximum score, 100 and 1.

When a participant has attended the class for the entire session we will send the maximum score or a percentage depending on how it’s set in the next field (LMS attendance score policy).

Set LMS attendance score policy by picking an option from the drop down menu.

This sets the policy for how attendance is scored and can be set to either Pass/Fail or a Percentage. This feature works in conjunction with the maximum score to calculate attendance.

Pass/Fail will send either the set attendance maximum score 100 or 1 (pass) or 0 (fail). Alternatively we can send a null instead of 0 for a fail, for more information see LMS attendance no-show policy.

Percentage will either send the score as a percentage based on the set attendance maximum score (0-100% or 0.00-1.00). Alternatively we can send a null instead of a failing score, for more information see LMS attendance no-show policy.

Set LMS attendance no-show policy by picking an option from the drop down menu.

This sets the behavior for users who have ‘not attended’ a class. This can be set to Send Nothing (not create an entry) or Send Score (based on above settings) if a participant has not met the attendance requirements.

Click Save Changes in the bottom right.

3 months ago Updated

You can add users in bulk to the class roster by uploading a CSV file. To update the roster with a CSV file:

Go to the Admin Portal.
Click Classes (Class Management in v3.0) the menu on the Left.
Select your class from the list of Active Classes or use the search field to find your class.
Click the class name.
Select Details.
Click the Roster tab.
Click the file icon to upload a CSV. 

Click the link for "Samples and templates here" to open the template as a Google Document.                                                                                

Choose File > Make a copy. 

 Fill out the .cvs file with a list of learners, instructors, and TAs who should be allowed to join this classroom.

When finished, go to File > Download > Comma-separated values (.csv, current sheet) to save to your computer.

Upload this roster from your computer using the file icon. 

Click Update.

Network and Firewall Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

For a seamless Engageli experience, ensure your network and firewall configurations are set up appropriately. Before checking the rest of the configurations, use Engageli’s Test Your System to ensure the permissions have been enabled for your audio and video devices. If user workstations have audio, video, and screen share system permissions locked, these will need to be allowed by an IT administrator to ensure the classroom functionality works correctly.

What are the URLs that are used to access the Engageli platform? 

If your whitelists allow wildcards, please add *.engageli.com and *.engageli-prod.com.

Do I need to open any specific network communication ports?

We use HTTPS over TCP for loading assets and the web app, and WebRTC over UDP for our video and audio streams. We also need access to STUN and TURN servers, and your Engageli representative can provide you with a connectivity test.

Are there specific client side / browser settings that need to be configured?

No, browser plug-ins are not needed. When you access Engageli for the first time, you will be prompted to allow permissions for your device microphone and camera.

What browser versions are currently supported?

Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, Brave on a Windows or MacOS device. The browser will require the user to access their microphone, camera, and screen sharing system permissions through their preferred or allowed browser. 

How are users authenticated on the platform, and how are they managed?

For larger deployments, we recommend an integration with your systems to provide authentication. This can either be a single-sign-on (SSO) integration with your identity provider, or an LTI 1.3 integration with a Learning Management System (LMS). The LTI 1.3 integration also provides additional capabilities around creation of Engageli classrooms and populating the roster. If you would like to talk about these options, please reach out to your Engageli representative.

Does accessing via VPN affect Engageli? 

Yes, we have noticed VPN connections degrade the user experience. If this is a requirement by your IT department, please let your Engageli representative know. Additionally, you can forward our IPs, Ports, and Protocols list below to your IT team to have them ensure Engageli will work with your VPN.

Can Quality of Service (QoS) rules be applied to specific types of traffic?

We recommend prioritizing Engageli traffic where possible.

How to Control Camera Functionality Upon Logging In
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Learner video streams are automatically enabled when they enter the class unless they've manually disabled their camera. As an instructor or administrator, you can adjust these permissions in our Admin Portal to ensure learner video streams are automatically disabled or enabled upon logging in.

Go to the Admin Portal.
Click Classes (Class Management in v3.0) from the menu on the Left.
Select your class from the list of Active Classes or use the search field to find your class.

Click the class name.
Select Details.
Click the Common Configuration (Configuration in v3.0) tab.
Click the Checkbox next to Turn off cameras upon login.
If the box is checked that means the feature has been activated and cameras will be automatically disabled when a learner logs in.
If the box is unchecked that means the feature is deactivated and cameras will automatically turn on unless manually disabled.
Click Save changes.

How to Update Classroom, Playback, and Common Settings
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

To access the Class Settings:

Go to the Admin Portal.
Click Classes (Class Management in v3.0) from the menu on the Left.
Select your class from the list of Active Classes or use the search field to find your class.

Click the class name.
Select Details.
Click the Live, Playback or Common Configuration (Configuration in v3.0) tab.
Make any changes to the settings.
Click Save Changes.

There are a number of settings that can be customized across an institution.

Settings

		If the setting is checked, it means that the setting is enabled. Uncheck a setting disable it.

 

New settings in 3.1

	Toxicity chat filter (English only) - Filters out offensive and inappropriate chat messages.

	Allow anonymous chat - Toggles the ability for learners to chat anonymously. 
	Create captions during live session - Allows instructors to enable captions during class
	Create caption vtt file when recording - Allows vtt file to be saved.
	Start class in table mode - Starts the session in table mode instead of room mode.
	Enable meeting mode - Disables the podium.
	K12 restrictions
	Track attendance by Occurence ID
	Send instructors email notifications on new questions in Q&A (playback) 
	Send TAs email notifications on new questions in Q&A (playback) 

Default Settings

	Allow table sharing - Allows participants to share screens at individual tables
	Allow recording of class gallery - Allows participant video feeds on the podium to be included in class recordings
	Auto start recording - Automatically starts the class recording after the instructor enters the classroom
	Turn off cameras upon login - Learner cameras will be turned off when first entering the classroom. Learners can turn them on. (This does not apply to instructors or TAs)
	Mute microphones upon entering - Learner microphones will be turned off when first entering the classroom. Learners can turn them on. (This does not apply to instructors or TAs)
	Allow peek into tables - Allows instructors using the Instructor Application to join and observe table activity unobtrusively.
	Open class in moderated mode (disabled for web-based instructor) - Allows instructors using the Instructor Application to approve or reject hand-raise requests for participants to go to the podium
	Enable clickable links in Chat - Allows participants to add clickable hyperlinks in the chat that open in new tabs
	Activate Engageli Tags automatically (PDF only) - Allows Engageli tags in PDFs to activate automatically when using the PDF Live Share
	Auto approve screen shares - Allows learner screen shares to be automatically approved without the instructor needing to take action 
	Allow learners to see other learners reactions- Makes reactions (thumbs up, thumbs down, heart, etc.) anonymous for all users
	Allow inviting guests to playback room

Understanding LMS Attendance
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

The LMS Attendance menu allows instructors and administrators to configure and manually sync attendance data to your learning management system.

Learning Management System attendance pass back must first be enabled at an organization level before data can be synced to your LMS.
Sessions

This is a list of all class sessions that have occurred and includes the following information:

Start and End time in your time zone, including the date.
Number of staff.
Number of students.
Date created.

If you don't see any sessions listed or the list is not correct, set a class schedule. This will help our system know when the class is scheduled to happen. Once you've set the schedule, you should see new sessions listed. For more information on how attendance is calculated, see this article.

To view the details of an individual session, click the row associated with the start and end time you'd like to learn more about. Once you do this, it will open in the Gradebook Sync tab.

Gradebook Sync

This tab contains details of an individual session and includes settings that control what and how we pass attendance data back to your learning management system as well as a button to manually sync data to your LMS.

The following settings are typically set by your Engageli administrator. 

LMS attendance maximum score

This sets the maximum attendance score possible for a participant. This can be set to a number between 1000000 and 1.

When a participant has attended the class for the entire session or enough to be counted as present we will send the maximum score or a percentage depending on how it’s set in the next field (LMS attendance score policy).

LMS attendance score policy by picking an option from the drop down menu.

This sets the policy for how attendance is scored and can be set to either Pass/Fail or a Percentage. This feature works in conjunction with the maximum score to calculate attendance.

Pass/Fail will send either the set attendance maximum score 100000-1 (pass) or 0 (fail). Alternatively we can send a null instead of 0 for a fail, for more information see LMS attendance no-show policy.

Percentage will either send the score as a percentage based on the set attendance maximum score (0-100% or 0.00-1.00). Alternatively we can send a null instead of a failing score, for more information see LMS attendance no-show policy.

LMS attendance no-show policy 

This sets the behavior for users who have ‘not attended’ a class. This can be set to Send Nothing (not create an entry) or Send Score (based on above settings) has not met the attendance requirements.

Session Ratio

This is a threshold (percentage) of class time that instructors are required to be logged into the class. The full duration of the class must be set via the Scheduler and this schedule is used to calculate occupancy. Once the instructor has occupied the class within the scheduled timeframe and meets the threshold, the session will be considered valid. By default, this value is set to 50%.

For example, if the Scheduler is set to 7 pm to 9 pm EST i.e. 120 minutes every Monday. If session ratio is set to 50%, that indicates the instructor should have been in class for 50% of the 120 minutes

Attendance Ratio

This is the threshold (percentage) of a session that a participant must attend to be considered present in the class. By default, this value is set to 60%.

To delete an active class from the Admin Portal, you have to archive it first.

 

Instructions

1. Go to the Admin Portal.

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class.

4. Click Details.

5. Under the General tab, click Archive Class.

6. Click Confirm.

7. Now that the class is archived, click Archived Classes on the left to expand the menu.

8. Select your archived class or use the search field to find it.

9. Click Details.

10. Under the General tab, click Delete Class.

11. Click Delete to confirm that you want to delete the class.

Note: This action cannot be undone.

Chat Analytics Overview
How to Access Engageli’s Chat Analytics

Follow these instructions to access Engageli’s Chat Analytics in the Admin Portal:

Go to the Admin Portal.
Click Classes (Class Management in v3.0) on the left to expand the menu.
Select your class or use the search field to find your class.
Click Analytics.
Select Chat.
Toggle between Chart and List View to see the data.
Select Export Chart CSV or Export CSV to download the data.
Chat Analytics Overview

Chat Analytics displays the number of chat messages sent per class (chart view) and per individual participant (list view). You can filter to include messages sent by staff or guests.

Total messages - Total number of chat messages sent during a class session
Private Messages - Number of messages sent from one participant to another
Everyone Messages - Number of messages sent by participants to the “Everyone” channel
Table Messages - Total number of messages sent by participants to their tablemates
Staff Messages - Total number of messages sent by participants to the “Staff” channel

 

  Chart View

Click an individual bar on the chart to drill down to view the Chat messages for the selected class.

List View

The List View displays a table showing the number and type of chat messages sent by each registered participant.

Name
Email address - Email address listed on the roster
Private - Number of messages sent by the participant to another individual participant
Everyone - Number of messages sent by the participant to the “Everyone” channel
Staff - Number of messages sent by the participant to the “Staff” channel
Table - Total number of messages sent by the participant to their tablemates
Total - Total number of messages sent by the participant

How to optimize for low bandwidth or CPU - Instructor (Browser)
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

If you are teaching on Engageli using an older computer or if you have low internet bandwidth or a slow network connection, you can adjust your settings to optimize your teaching experience.

 

1. Check your internet connection 

Other computers/devices using the same network can cause the network to slow down, which can result in audio and video issues. 

2. Switch to low bandwidth mode

Click the three dots menu at the bottom of your screen, and then click Low bandwidth mode. This mode will save bandwidth by automatically merging the gallery view into one video feed and turning off learner video feeds when they are on the podium and in the table mates gallery when you visit individual tables. You will still hear each learner’s audio.

3. Mute your audio

Your audio doesn’t use as much bandwidth as your video, but you can reduce your bandwidth by muting your audio when you’re not speaking, there’s a panel discussion, or when learners doing group activities.

4. Turn off your video

When showing video clips or when learners are engaged in peer-to-peer and group activities, turn off your video feed to lower your computer’s CPU usage and improve network traffic. 

5. Screen share only when necessary

Make sure to stop sharing when you no longer need to show a tab, window, or your screen. You can upload slides or a presentation to the chat for learners to view on their own devices.

6. Close other applications

To free up more network resources, close other applications and programs you do not need during your Engageli session. 


 

For optimal performance with Engageli, we recommend keeping your operating system and browsers up to date. You may have trouble using certain features on Engageli if you are joining your virtual classroom in parallel with CPU-intensive applications such as cloud computing and streaming services.

Analytics - Using Engagement Data
5 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Engageli collects a wide variety of engagement data, both aggregated and individual, that can be used to identify opportunities for improvement in the design and delivery of instruction.

Raise Hand Analytics

Engageli’s Raise Hand feature allows participants at tables to address the entire classroom from the podium. Instructors can use this data to track engagement during their sessions and answer questions such as:

Which learners are participating in the session (and which are not)?
Am I, as the instructor, actively involving my learners in the session by asking questions, soliciting feedback, and asking them to share?

Chat Analytics

Chats can make virtual learning more efficient as questions are answered in real-time in context with instruction. Chat messages increase opportunities for learner-to-learner collaboration, as well as learner-to-instructor interaction. Chat also allows learners who are not able to turn on their microphone or camera to still actively participate in class by sending messages, uploading materials, collaborating with their tablemates, and engaging in community-building or other learning activities.

A classroom with a larger percentage of messages sent to tablemates rather than private, 1-on-1 messages could reflect strong collaboration among the learners.

Poll Analytics

Polls can be presented in the course material as checks for comprehension and engagement in real-time. Using polls provides instructors an opportunity to adjust the pace of the class and can foster a discussion about the results in an effort to make the material more understandable. Polls also allow learners who are not able to turn on their microphone or camera to participate in checks for understanding or community-building polls, which can be used to determine learning gains, engagement, and if individual attention is required.

Poll participation can indicate learner sentiment about instructional pedagogies used during the class.

Speak Time Analytics

Speak time is an important element of learning. Not only does talking help learners process the information presented during a lesson, it also promotes peer-to-peer learning and builds connections and community. Opportunities for table discussion (private to the table and never recorded) provide learners psychological safety and time to reflect and collaborate on the concepts presented. Interlacing class time with group activities at tables can provide structured ways for learners to practice critical thinking and reflect on the content presented.

Measuring learner speak time helps instructors understand the participation equity of learners in the class. It can also help instructors redesign their class session plans by incorporating additional time for group activities to increase speaking time and overall engagement in the classroom.

Reviewing the total learner speaking time vs instructor speaking time can help determine the proportion of direct instruction during a class.

Attendance Analytics

Research shows that attendance is an important factor in learner achievement, as learners are more likely to succeed in academics when they attend class sessions consistently and are exposed to instruction.

Attendance data can also be used to identify learners who are not attending and potentially falling behind, or who might need a success coach to reach out to ensure retention. Playback Room attendance data can be used to track whether absent or asynchronous learners review class recordings and engage with the course material and if follow-up attention is needed.

Grades

Grades allow instructors to evaluate learners and provide feedback on their work and performance.

Grades recorded in Engageli can be used to identify learners who are falling behind, are having trouble with retention, or need individual support, supplemental instruction, or tutoring.

How to Customize Attendance and Session Ratios
8 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Super admins can set a customized attendance threshold for an institution.

See below for details on attendance tracking and the parameters that can be set for your institution. 

Attendance Ratio - This is the threshold (percentage) of a session that a participant must attend to be considered present in the class. The default is 60%.

Session Ratio - This is a threshold (percentage) of class time that instructors are required to be logged into the class. The full duration of the class must be set via the Scheduler and this schedule is used to calculate occupancy. Once the instructor has occupied the class within the scheduled timeframe and meets the threshold, the session will be considered valid. The default is 50%.

To customize attendance parameters for an institution:

Go to the Admin Portal.
Click Site Management from the menu on the left.
Select the Class Configuration tab.
Enter an Attendance ratio and a Session ratio.
Click Save Changes.

Note: The attendance ratio and session ratio will apply to all classes for the institution. Individual instructors cannot change the established attendance and session ratio percentages. 

Click here to learn about how attendance is calculated.

How to Split Learners into Tables Based on Poll Results
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Polls can be used to gather learner opinions, surface common misconceptions, and challenge learners to identify the best answer to a question.

Similar to random table arrangements, instructors can split learners into table groups based on similar or dissimilar poll responses. This is applicable only to single-answer polls.

When to use:

If most learners answer the same question correctly, it may not be worth the class time to discuss the results. If learners are split in their responses, invite them to discuss with other learners to probe for differences and clarify misconceptions. Use this feature to divide the learners into small groups. (You can even re-run the poll after learners discuss their responses with peers.)
Splitting learners into table groups based on similar poll results can be a good way to help learners get to know each other during icebreakers, share a common interest, prepare group responses to discussion questions, group learners for projects based on topic interest or prepare for debates conducted via a Panel Discussion.

Split learners based on poll results during the poll:

Instructions

Run the poll in your shared presentation or PDF.
Click Start Poll Split.
Select whether you want to split learners by Diverse or Common responses.
Use the slider to the maximum number of learners you want at each table. (TAs won’t be moved to a different table.)
Use the slider to choose the number of learners per table.
If you want to reserve [skip in Engageli 3.0] or set aside certain tables, use the slider to select the tables.
Click Split [Confirm in Engageli 3.0].

Learners can be split into groups of 1-10 learners, depending on the number of seats at each table. Click here to learn how to change the number of seats at a table. Click here to learn more about skipping tables during the split-by-poll arrangement.

Note: In situations where learners do not answer the poll question, they are considered as if the poll has an additional answer possibility (i.e., “did not want to answer”), and will be split into table groups based on dissimilar responses.

You can also split learners based on poll results at any point during the class from the Tables Tab. Click here to learn more.

Basic Troubleshooting

1. Check that you are using a computer or laptop to run class. We currently do not support mobile or tablet devices. If you are using one of these, please join Engageli via a laptop, computer, or Chromebook.

2. Check that you are on an Engageli-supported browser. We currently do not recommend Safari or Firefox browsers. If you are using one of these, please join Engageli via the latest version of Google Chrome, Edge, or a browser on Chromium (Opera, Vivaldi, Brave).

3. Refresh the browser. Sometimes, simply refreshing the browser can resolve an audio issue. 

4. Check your computer’s permissions (Mac | Windows). Check the privacy and security settings for your computer’s Microphone, and make sure they are set to On and that desktop apps have access to the Microphone. 

 

Troubleshooting During Class

Check your device's sound output and make sure the correct devices are connected. You can check your speaker output in your settings (gear icon). This will open a media device settings window where you can toggle which speaker Engageli is using. 

Troubleshooting Headsets


Note: If you are running an additional audio/video platform, this can sometimes prevent Engageli from accessing your audio device.

Bluetooth headphones:


Disconnect your headphones from your computer.

Turn your headphones off or put your earbuds in their charging case.

Check that the audio works on your internal computer speakers.

Turn your headphones back on or remove your earbuds from their case.

Reconnect your headphones or earbuds to your computer.

USB headphones:


Disconnect your headphones from your computer’s USB port.

Check that the audio works on your internal computer speakers.

Plug your headphones into a different port, if possible.


1/8” (3.5mm) connector headphones:

Remove your headphones from your computer’s 1/8” jack.

Check that the audio works on your internal computer speakers.

Plug your headphones back into the 1/8” jack.

How to Skip Tables During Split by Poll Table Arrangements
18 days ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Similar to creating random table arrangements, instructors can split learners into table groups based on similar or dissimilar poll responses. You can now easily skip or set aside tables during these table arrangements.

 

The number of tables to skip corresponds to the first nine tables in the classroom, left to right. If you choose to skip 1 table, no learners will be assigned to Table 1. If you choose to skip 2 tables, no learners will be assigned to Table 1 or Table 2. All users (learners, TAs, and instructors) can take part in polls, but TAs won’t be re-arranged when you use the “Split Learners by Poll Results” feature. If they are placed at a skipped table, they will remain at the table, but no other learners will be assigned to that table.

Instructions

Run the poll in your shared presentation or PDF. (Note: Splitting learners based on poll results is applicable only for single-answer polls.)
Click Start Poll Split.
Select whether you want to split learners by Diverse or Common responses.
Use the slider to the maximum number of learners you want at each table. (TAs won’t be moved to a different table.)
Use the slider to choose the number of learners per table.
If you want to reserve [skip in Engageli 3.0] or set aside certain tables, use the slider to select up to the first 3 tables.
Click Split [Confirm in Engageli 3.0].

When to use:
When you have support individuals, such as teaching assistants, administrative staff, or mentors who will not take part in table activities based on poll results
When you have a dedicated support table, with individuals who you’d like to place at that table to assist learners 
When you have someone observing your teaching and you’d like to place them at a set table so you can join and discuss their observations while learners work in their table groups
When you have guests who you would like to place at one table so you can join the table and discuss the poll results or other content while learners work in their table groups
When you have guests who you would like to place at one table so you can easily add them to a panel or ask them to join the podium

How to Manage the Chat
5 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

Instructors in virtual classrooms have to balance presenting their educational material, navigating the features of the platform as well as holding their learners' attention and keeping them engaged. Engageli’s Chat feature allows instructors to communicate directly with learners, and learners to communicate directly with each other. Here are some tips for managing the chat so you can foster communication and engagement and conduct your Engageli session with ease.

1. Learn your chat channels

Everyone - All participants in the class

Staff - All instructors and TAs in the class

TAs - All users logged in as TAs

Learner name - Specific learner

Table – If you change the table names, you will see the customized table names in the chat channels menu.

2. Set ground rules

Learners might use the chat to carry on discussions unrelated to the class session. Establish ground rules a the beginning of the session if you have rules you want the learners to follow such as keeping side conversations to a minimum or not overusing emojis, acronyms, shorthand, etc.

3. Post Questions in the Q&A

If you have questions for your learners that you don’t want to get lost in the chat, you can post them in the Q&A. The Q&A is threaded, persists, and asynchronous learners watching the class recording in the Playback Room will also be able to participate. Like the chat, the Q&A can be downloaded.

4. Designate a Moderator

If you have teaching assistants (TA), you can assign them or another learner to be the moderator and keep track of the chat. The chat moderator can answer questions without distracting from a presentation or lecture and also alert you to pertinent questions or comments via a private chat to you or the “Staff” channel.

5. Download the chat for later review

During a session, learners may actively participate in the chat, posting questions, responding, and helping each other. If you are not able to keep up with the chat in real-time, you can download the chat at the end of class for later review so that you can address any outstanding questions or issues in the next class.

After you run the poll, continue with your instruction.
Select the Tables tab when you are ready to split the learners into tables based on the poll.
Under the Seating Arrangement drop-down menu, select Split Students by Poll Results.                                                                          
Select whether you want to split learners by Diverse or Common responses.
Use the slider to choose the number of learners per table. (TAs won’t be moved to a different table.)
If you want to reserve [skip in Engageli 3.0] or set aside certain tables, use the slider to select the tables.
Click Split [Confirm in Engageli 3.0].

Learners can be split into groups of 1-10 learners, depending on the number of seats at each table. Click here to learn how to change the number of seats at a table.

Note: In situations where learners do not answer the poll question, they are considered as if the poll has an additional answer possibility (i.e., “did not want to answer”), and will be split into table groups based on dissimilar responses.

You can also split learners into tables based on the poll results directly from the poll. Click here to learn more.

Camera Issues - PC
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

 

Camera issues can happen for a number of reasons. First, check that your camera is on and that you've granted camera permissions.

If that doesn't work, we're here to help!

Click here if you use a Mac. 

 

Granting Camera Permission during Class 

Granting Camera Permission from Browser

Granting Camera Permission from Computer

Is an Anti-Virus Disabling Your Camera?

 

 

Checking Your Camera During Class 

1. Make sure the camera image indicates that your camera is on. If the camera icon is red, then your camera is off.

 

2. Check that you have connected the correct camera to the Engageli classroom through Settings (gear icon).

 

Granting Permission to Use Camera from Browser

 

Google Chrome

1. Click "Allow" on the pop-up permission prompt when you first log into your class. 

 

2. If you do not see this option, click on the lock icon in the top left corner of your screen next to your address bar. Make sure the camera is toggled to "Allow."

 

 

Edge

1. Click"Allow" on the pop-up permission prompters when you first log into your class.

 

2. If this is not an option, click on the lock icon in the top left corner of your screen next to your address bar. Ensure from this menu that your camera is set to "Allow."





 

Granting Permission to Use Camera from Computer (PC)

 

1. Go to your system settings, which you can find by searching "settings" in your finder.

 

 

2. Next, click on "Privacy" from the resulting menu.

 

3. Click "Camera" from the privacy menu.

4. Make sure that your camera is allowed on your device (which is the default), and that "Allow apps to access your camera" is toggled on.

 

 

5. Next, scroll down to "Allow desktop apps to access your camera," and ensure that this is toggled on. You should see Engageli on this list.

 

 

 

Is an Anti Virus Disabling Your Camera?

If none of the above steps solve the camera issue, it is possible that an anti-virus application is disabling your camera. The Kaspersky Anti-Virus software is most commonly seen.

Windows

1. Go to the taskbar and search for the application "Kapersky Internet Security."

2. Navigate to "Privacy Protection" and click on "Webcam Protection." 

 

3. Clicking on the link will reveal checkable boxes. Be sure that "Block access to webcam for all applications" is not marked with a check.

 

4. You can then restart your computer and try using your webcam again.

How to Optimize Your Class Recording for Asynchronous Learning
3 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

When recording a class on Engageli, follow the guidelines below to ensure an optimized recording for asynchronous learning in the Playback room.

 

Included in the recording	NOT included in the recording:
Instructor audio/video	Instructor audio/video when visiting tables
Learner audio/video the podium (raised hands)	Learner video while at tables
Learner audio in Room Mode	Conversations at tables in Table Mode
Screen shares to the entire class	Screen shares to tables
Panels	Learner reactions (thumbs up/down)
Video clips	Miro whiteboard
Polls/quizzes	Shared table documents
Engageli class whiteboards	 
Engageli table whiteboards*	 
Shared class documents	 
Class Gallery*	 

 

Class Materials 

If you are not sharing materials such as a presentation deck or document during the class, your instructor video will appear in a large view in the recording. If you do not want to appear in a large view in the recording, then you should continue to share your screen.

Learner Video

Learners' video feeds in the Class Gallery under My View are not recorded by default for privacy reasons. You can enable the recording of the Class Gallery in the Admin Portal. Click here to learn how class recordings can be configured to include or exclude your learners’ video feeds or the Class Gallery [Engageli 3.1 only].

Learner Audio

In Room Mode, which is the Engageli default, learners will be recorded regardless of whether they raise their hands or not. Room Mode captures all audio in the classroom. 
Discussions that happen at the tables when Table Mode is enabled are not recorded.

Tables and Group Activities 

If you are doing group activities, and are visiting tables, the recording will not pause automatically. If you are conducting group activities within the tables, you should pause the recording until you regroup so that there is no blank air time. 

Collaborative Features

If you run a poll during your class, as an ice breaker or to check for understanding, learners watching the recording can also participate in the poll. After you turn on the poll, the poll will be displayed in the recording. If you want asynchronous learners to see the live results, click "Share Results" in the live session. Asynchronous learners will need to answer the poll before seeing the live results.
Any questions posted in the Q&A during the live class will be displayed in the Playback Room. Learners watching the recording can answer the same questions that were posed in the live session. The questions will appear to any learner who attended, whether during the live session or viewing the recording in the Playback Room.
Messages sent in the Chat are not included in the recording and do not persist in the Playback room.
If you distribute a Class or Table Whiteboard to learners during the session, these will be included in the recording. We recommend instructing asynchronous learners to replicate any whiteboard activities done in the live class, as the host can open a whiteboard in the Playback Room.

New in Engageli 3.1!

In Engageli 3.1, instructors can change their settings to include the Class Gallery in recordings. Table whiteboards are also included in the class recording when viewed in an Engageli Playback Room.

 

 Need more help? Contact Support.

This article will show you how to share a PowerPoint presentation in Engageli, use the Presenter View, and see your presentation notes. 

Click here for instructions if you are using a Mac.

Quick Overview

Instructions

Make sure you are logged into your Engageli classroom.
Open your PowerPoint Presentation. 
Click the Slide Show tab.
Check "Use Presenter View". (Use you can also select this under Set Up Slide Show.) 
Click the SlideShow icon on the bottom right to start the slide show. 
Your slide show will open up in full screen on your single monitor.
Hover near the bottom left of the screen and then click the three dots menu.
Select Show Presenter View. 
The Presenter View opens in a separate window. 
You can minimize the Presenter View window so you can use it after you share the presentation. 
To get back to your Engageli classroom, hold down the Window key and then click the tab key. 
You will see all the windows you have open. Select the browser window with the Engageli classroom open. 
Once back in the Engageli classroom, to share your screen, click the Present button at the bottom of the screen.

Under Classroom activities, click Screen Share.

Select Window.

Select the PowerPoint slide show. Once highlighted, the Share button will become enabled.
Click Share.
Your display will shift to your presentation.
Repeat step 11 [Window key + tab] to get back to the Engageli classroom.
Select the Presenter View window from your bottom tool bar. 
You can resize and position the Presenter View window onto of your Engageli classroom. 

Note: Remember to hold down the Window key and then press the Tab key when you want to change windows or views.

The Live Configuration section of our Admin Portal allows Admins and Instructors to control basic settings for each class.

Access the admin portal.
Click Classes in the left menu.
Select the Live Configuration tab.
Check or uncheck the box next to each setting.
Click Save Changes.
Maximum number of seats per table

This sets the maximum number of students who can be seated at a table.

Table sharing (screen sharing to your table)

Allows users to share their screen with their table for group activities.

Allow hybrid groups (will block roster seating)

Control the ability to turn allow hybrid groups.

Record learner videos

Control the ability to record learners' video stream while on the podium.

Class gallery recording

Control the ability to record the entire class gallery.

Automatically start recording

This will automatically start recording a class once the instructor joins and the recorder is online.

Allow third-party content generation

This will enable our recording AI summary. If the class is recorded and transcribed, we will summarize it in the playback room. For more information see this article.

Allow peek into tables

Control the ability for instructors to join a table without being seen or heard.

Activate Engageli tags automatically (PDF only).

Engageli Action tags will automatically activate as soon as the slide is shared (PDF only).

How to Access Engageli’s Attendance Analytics
Attendance Analytics Overview
How to Access Engageli’s Attendance Analytics

Follow these instructions to access Engageli’s Attendance Analytics in the Admin Portal:

Go to the Admin Portal.
Click Classes (Class Management in v3.0) on the left to expand the menu.
Select your class or use the search field to find your class.
Click Analytics.
Select Attendance.
Toggle between Chart and List View to see the data. To see a list of individual users, click on List View.
Select Export CSV to download the data.
Attendance Analytics Overview

Attendance Analytics displays the number of attendees for a class session (live and playback). Engageli measures the total minutes of each class session as well as the minutes each participant attended. Engageli measures the percentage of class session time a participant attended each class session, whether synchronously or asynchronously in an Engageli Playback Room. You can filter by participant: learners, staff, and guests. You also filter by class type: Live (synchronous) or Playback (asynchronous).

Attendee - Individual who attends a class session (live or playback)
Attendance (%) - Average percentage of class sessions with “present” attendance across all classes held during the specified time period
Attendance tracking for participants is based on the participant attending at least 60% of the instructor's attendance. If an instructor is logged in for a 1-hour session, the participant needs to attend the session for at least 36 minutes in order to be marked as present. 
Lecture duration - The total scheduled class time
Presence (HH:MM) - Amount of time participants spent in class (compared to the total class time), based on the scheduled time
Offline or Playback room attendance - Participant watched at least 60% of the recorded class time. If the recorded session is below 60% of the class time, attendance is not marked as present even if the participant watches the entire recorded session.

 Engageli 3.1 Feature 

This feature is available in Engageli 3.1. Click to learn more about Engageli 3.1. Click to read the Engageli 3.1 release notes.

You can create structured Modules for each unit of your course by adding Tasks within a Module. Each Task within the Module must be completed by the learner within the Playback Room before moving to the next Task, and Modules can also be set to be completed in the required order.

Go to your Class Portal.

Click the Save button.
You can also re-order Modules.
Hover over the assignment that you want to move.
When the Module is highlighted, click and hold your mouse on the Module. Drag & drop to reorder the Modules.

How to Upload Roster Seating Plans

This article includes:

Access table presets in the Engageli Admin Portal

Prepare your classroom for table assignments

Prepare your roster and table names

Upload class roster

Apply Roster Seating in the classroom

When Roster Seating is used in a classroom, learners are assigned to specific tables initially set up on the class roster in the Admin Portal. These serve as default table assignments. Tables can be pre-assigned to learners so that they will automatically be placed at the table you decide. If no table is pre-assigned, the learner will be placed automatically at the next available seat.

Access table presets in the Engageli Admin Portal

1. Go to the Admin Portal.

2. Click Class Management on the left to expand the menu. 

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class. 

4. Click Tables & Preset.

Prepare your classroom for table assignments

After you click Tables & Presets, you will see tabs for Tables and Presets. An Engageli classroom opens with 5 tables, each with 10 seats, by default. As the tables fill with learners, more tables are added automatically. However, you can manually add tables 5 at a time but be careful not to add too many, as currently they cannot be removed.

To add tables, click the plus sign icon in the top right corner of the Tables tab.

To add custom table names, click the table name to edit and make changes.

 

Prepare your roster and table names

You can find a template to import your roster and table names and assignments here. To find this template in the Admin Portal:

1. Click Class Management on the left to expand the menu. 

2. Select your class or use the search field to find your class. 

3. Click Details.

4. Select the Roster tab.

5. Click the Update class with a CSV icon.

6. Click the link for samples and templates.

 

Follow the instructions to create a copy of the template in Google Sheets (or download to Excel).

1. Paste or type in the email addresses and names of your learners (columns A and B).

2. Role should be set to “Learner” (column C).

3. Ensure the Table group name matches the name in the portal (column E).

4. Select File -> Download -> Comma Separated Values (.csv). The sheet will be exported as a CSV file into your Downloads folder. You may want to rename the file if you are doing multiple classrooms.

 
Upload class roster

 

After you create your roster file, go to the Roster tab in the Admin Portal (Details > Roster).

1. Click the Update Class with a CSV icon.

2. Click BROWSE to select the CSV file from your computer.

3. Click UPDATE.

4. This will update your class, populate the roster and assign table seating.

 

Apply Roster Seating in the classroom

When you enter your classroom to teach, go to the TABLES view.

From the Seating Arrangement drop-down menu, select Roster Seating.

 

Any learners present who have a table assigned will be placed automatically at the right table immediately, and as more learners join they will too.

Any learners who are not assigned to a table, or who are not on the roster, will be assigned a seat at the next available table.

Open your Google Slides presentation.
Click the down arrow next to Slideshow in the upper right corner.
Click Presenter View. 
Go back to your Engageli classroom window.
To share your screen, click the Present button at the bottom of the screen.

Under Classroom activities, click Screen Share.

Select either Browser Tab or Window.

Select Google Slides presentation slide show. Once highlighted, the Share button will become enabled.
Click Share.
Your display will shift to your presentation.
If sharing a tab, click the View tab: button at the top of the screen or select the tab with the red dot to go back to your Engageli classroom. If sharing a window, go back to the Engageli classroom window. 
You can move your Google Slides Preview screen over the Engageli classroom to present your slides and view any speaker notes and the timer. Only your slides will be visible to the class. 

Pro tip! Use the overlay gallery to see a smaller version of the class gallery that you can move around the while so you can still see your learners while screen sharing or giving a presentation.

3 months ago Updated

Collaborative class files are now included in classroom recordings viewed in Engageli Playback Rooms.

 

A class document is a file that opens for the entire class to view and edit directly on the Engageli screen. Instructors can use this feature to distribute a file to learners to collaborate in real-time for full-class contributions/activities. When instructors record their sessions, shared class documents are available for asynchronous learners who view the recording in the Playback Room.

In the class recording, there's a marker to show when the document was shared. When the viewer reaches that point in the recording, the document will open in a new tab at the top of the screen. The viewer can add to the document as well as see the contributions of their classmates from the live class.

Note: Viewers should pause the recording before working on a collaborative class doc in a Playback Room.

Teaching Tips for Class Recordings and Class Docs
Share a class-wide collaborative doc (Google materials or Microsoft 365 materials) during the live session and have verbal and written instructions for asynchronous learners to contribute and collaborate on these materials in the Playback Room.
Use discussion prompts, group work, and class collaborative documents in your live instruction.
Use video clips, polls for icebreakers and assessments, collaborative materials, and the Q&A to make your recording more engaging.
Collaborative class materials shared during the live class session will appear in the Playback room for async learners to contribute and use for similar learning activities.
Detail activity instructions in multiple modalities and places (verbally in the class recording, written on presented slides, detailed in the class collaborative doc, posted in the LMS announcements or message board, and/or in the Q&A).
Detail the recommended time for activities and instruct asynchronous learners to pause the recording to complete the activity (for “think time” and “do-now’s”).

How to Set Up and Distribute Documents
2 months ago Updated
Follow
Not yet followed by anyone

You can distribute a shared document to the entire class or separate documents to each table so that learners can work collaboratively within the Engageli classroom.

Learners will be able to see and edit documents directly on the Engageli screen. This is great for brainstorming sessions, in-class group assignments, worksheets, or presentation preparation.

Note: This feature is best used for files that you want learners to edit together in class. If you wish to simply share notes, presentations, or other files with the class, it is best to upload the file in the Chat. A comprehensive guide on how to use the chat can be found here.

Class Document and Table Documents
Distribute Documents in Class
Prepare Shared Table Documents in the Admin Portal
Class Document and Table Documents

You distribute two kinds of documents in Engageli: a class document or table documents.

A class document is a file that opens for the entire class to view and edit directly on the Engageli screen.

When to use: You can use this feature to distribute a file to learners to collaborate in real-time for full class contributions/activities.

A table document is a file that opens for a particular table. You can have the same file open or different files for different tables.

When to use: You can use this feature to distribute a file to learners to collaborate in real-time on table-based activities, peer-to-peer instruction, station-based work, case studies per table, etc. You can distribute:
One document shared with all tables
Individual documents shared per table

For either a class document or separate table documents, you can share the following types of files:

Google Document, Sheet, and Slides
Microsoft 365 Word, Excel, and Powerpoint

Note: Microsoft 365 files open within Engageli in view-only mode. For editing, the files will open in a new tab.

Distribute Documents in Class

You can distribute documents in class without any prior setup.

1. Start your class.

2. When you are ready to distribute the documents, click the Present button at the bottom of the screen.

3. Select either Distribute Doc or Distribute Docs.

4. For a classroom doc, paste the link to the file you want to share and then click the Share button.

5. For table documents, select the set of files you want to share if you added them to the Admin Portal before class, or click the plus sign to add the links.

Note: You have to add links for each table, even if it’s the same file for each table.

Pro tip! Save time by adding table document links to the Admin Portal before class. Add them in the Materials section. At this time, shared class document links cannot be added beforehand, only shared table documents.

6. Learners will then see the document you have shared and be able to edit directly on the documents. 

You can change the links to be shared at any point during the class.

After enabling a shared doc, you will see a prompt to change the classroom audio to Table Mode.

7. When you are ready to collect the documents, click the Present button again, and then Stop. After clicking, learners will no longer be able to see or edit the document.

Prepare Shared Table Documents in the Admin Portal

1. Go to the Admin Portal.

2. Click Class Management on the left to expand the menu.

3. Select your class or use the search field to find your class.

4. Click Materials.  

5. If you have sub-rooms created, click which room you want to add materials to, and then select the plus sign.

6. Give the set a name.

7. Select which type of files you want to share (G-Suite or Office 365).

8. Click Add.

9. Paste the shared links for the files you want to distribute in class. You can distribute one document per table. Learners seated at that table will be shown that document after activating the feature during class. 

10. Confirm that the linked documents are made editable for/by your class before distributing them. You should do this directly in the Google file or Microsoft 365 file that you plan to share.

Starting a Panel

To start a panel, you simply add learners to the panel.

Basic Troubleshooting

Troubleshooting During Class

Troubleshooting Headsets

 
Basic Troubleshooting

1. Check that you are using a computer or laptop to run class. We currently do not support mobile or tablet devices. If you are using one of these, please join Engageli via a laptop, computer, or Chromebook.

2. Check that you are on an Engageli-supported browser. We currently do not recommend Safari or Firefox browsers. If you are using one of these, please join Engageli via the latest version of Google Chrome, Edge, or a browser on Chromium (Opera, Vivaldi, Brave).

3. Refresh the browser. Sometimes, simply refreshing the browser can resolve an audio issue. 

4. Check your computer’s permissions (Mac | Windows). Check the privacy and security settings for your computer’s Microphone, and make sure they are set to On and that desktop apps have access to the Microphone. 

 

Troubleshooting During Class

Check your device's sound output and make sure the correct devices are connected. You can check your speaker output in your settings (gear icon). This will open a media device settings window where you can toggle which speaker Engageli is using. 

Troubleshooting Headsets


Note: If you are running an additional audio/video platform, this can sometimes prevent Engageli from accessing your audio device.

Bluetooth headphones:


Disconnect your headphones from your computer.

Turn your headphones off or put your earbuds in their charging case.

Check that the audio works on your internal computer speakers.

Turn your headphones back on or remove your earbuds from their case.

Reconnect your headphones or earbuds to your computer.

USB headphones:


Disconnect your headphones from your computer’s USB port.

Check that the audio works on your internal computer speakers.

Plug your headphones into a different port, if possible.


1/8” (3.5mm) connector headphones:

Remove your headphones from your computer’s 1/8” jack.

Check that the audio works on your internal computer speakers.

Plug your headphones back into the 1/8” jack.


Click here for information about the audio settings in an Engageli classroom.
